Mr. President, first of all, congratulations to the rapporteur of the Sarnac, who has done an excellent job of synthesis, even in a context in which the Commission and especially the Council have not always shown great openness to the requests of this Parliament.
The Development Commission has approved my report unanimously. Some of our observations have been accepted. On other points, we are still rather dissatisfied.

However, we take a step back with a sense of responsibility, considering it paramount to approve the entire package in first reading, which guarantees the start of the process on the next January 1st.
It is great that the funds for students have been quadrupled, but beware, a significant portion comes from resources intended for development, DCI and Cotonou.
We will therefore be strict in demanding absolute respect for the overall regulatory framework, particularly in relation to the DCI.

For now, I send my best wishes to the many European young people from all over the world who, with a spirit of friendship, sharing, desire to learn and grow, will be the protagonists of this extraordinary experience.
Accident. Congratulations to the speaker.
As a member of the Petitions Committee, based on the data, the report and also my personal experience, I would like to express my thanks and an invitation to the public.

A thank you because the progress compared to the previous year is evident. We have gone from 449 to 518 admissible cases, from 12 to 16 per cent of the total, with an increase also in the investigations carried out.
I therefore believe that the path taken is a good one.
However, and here I am responding to the invitation, we still need to increase our efforts in terms of communication.
Let's study together effective ways, perhaps starting from our schools, to ensure citizens are provided with quality information on the figure, role and skills of the European mediator.
There are interesting projects in this sense that have started this year and need to be implemented and supported.
In this way, the already good current figures will certainly continue to improve.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, our primary objective is to ensure that Europe has a Common Agricultural Policy even after 2013.

We believe that this is fundamental not only to protect the agricultural sector and the socio-economic fabric in the Member States, but also because at the dawn of the third millennium it is strategically necessary to ensure Europe food security.

Madam Commissioner, we would like to stress that it is necessary to continue to implement policies supporting single farms where this is needed, and in particular we believe that in the tobacco sector, the decoupling of aid should provide for the possibility of

To maintain a partial coupled aid until 2013, in order to avoid the total abandonment of production, as this would put entire supply chains at risk, creating unemployment as well as various economic and environmental problems in particularly disadvantaged areas.
I would like to remind the Commissioner and the President that the European Parliament has already expressed a favorable opinion by a large majority on this issue.

b) in the dairy sector, in order to rebalance the market in the short term and to allow a smooth exit from the quota system in the long term, it would be appropriate to increase the quotas by 2% for each marketing campaign from 2009-2010 to 2014-2015.
President, Madam Commissioner, Honourable Colleagues, I am very pleased to take the test of the Commission as very positive.
co-decision in the agricultural field, which was given through the reinforced collaboration between Council, Commission and European Parliament.
It is a good omen, and I will also allow myself to congratulate, naturally, the Honourable Capolasantos for his balanced
Report on modulation, on young farmers, on safety in the workplace, as well as facing new challenges.
We are in a difficult transition, we know the Prodo and decoupling, other innovative measures, we must protect in this transition the breeders in
in view of the abolition of milk quotas, as well as disadvantaged areas, such as those in the tobacco sector. And we must take advantage of this transition to start a serious reflection
After 2013, to update the purposes and the new missions of the PAC and to start discussing the overcoming of the dichotomy between the first and second pillar.

Mr. President, I appreciate the great efforts of our rapporteur Capolas Santos to keep the CAP closer to farmers and European citizens rather than to market needs and to reconcile the different concerns in the face of the many challenges at stake.
It is therefore essential to have a common approach by the 27 States on the sector, but it is important to maintain the tools for supporting and managing the markets for the main productions.

I am thinking, for example, of the dairy sector or tobacco subsidies, whose abolition would certainly not contribute to a reduction in smoking, but rather to the elimination of an important European production and the social fabric that is linked to it.
However, such tools must always take into account the extremely varied reality of the European landscape.
The current milk quota system, for example, meets criteria that are now obsolete.
The 1% increase proposed by the compromise is not enough to meet the internal demand of most Member States.

A more flexible system is therefore needed, which offers each individual Member State the possibility of responding to its own needs, which would also favour the European competitiveness of the sector on the international market.
Mr. President, our group is quite satisfied with these two proposals.

We are fairly satisfied, although not entirely, as demonstrated by the number of amendments we have tried to contribute to improve these texts, and fairly satisfied for a lack of ambition. We think that more and better could have been done.
There are signs of openness, of civility, which are immediately followed, even in the debate within this Parliament, by signs of rigidity, especially from the Council, of strong protectionism.

This also concerns the Blue Card. There is resistance on some central principles, such as equal work, equal pay, which is a sacred and natural principle, but even on this we have found some points of contention.

We believe it is essential to overcome the principle of community preference, to overcome the idea that there is a Europe that travels at two speeds, which is why it is necessary to make the principle of community preference prevail.
We believe that the call to the labour market is important, but the labour market cannot be the only regulatory principle.
There are other inclusive principles of political and social civilization that must be part of immigration policies.
Legal immigration means equal dignity and opportunities, or do we go back to immigration à la carte, selective, partial, discriminatory?
We would like to avoid it.

For this reason too, on behalf of the group, I support the proposal of colleague Moreno addressed to the Commission. Let's try to think of a blue card that is not only linked to that 3% of highly qualified immigrants, but that seeks to find legal and concrete tools to open the market to immigration.
Immigration must be inclusive; if it becomes selective, it is no longer a positive policy.

Honorable Huckmark, honorable Toia, one minute. Faced with the very serious crisis that is affecting the automotive sector, from America to our continent, Europe is faced with a very clear dilemma: either stand still and watch this collapse in demand and production,

production whose effects cannot even be calculated today, in the name of an abstract coherence, for a theoretical model of market liberalism, of total respect for competition, as some voices have been heard even today, or to take responsibility to adequately face the situation.
We are definitely in favor of this second choice and we ask the Commission and the Council to make a decision and be determined.
We appreciated Commissioner Feruggen's words and we hope that some colleagues will not slow down this determination too much.
It is an exceptional situation, so the responses must be exceptional as well.

Moreover, dear colleagues, the financial crisis has shown us some interventions by political and economic authorities that have made choices of behavior, of investment of public resources that until a few months before were unthinkable.

But our intervention, and I conclude, must be selective, reconciling strategy with emergency, supporting, both through facilitated credits and demand support, a selective orientation towards environmentally more sustainable productions.
Thank you, President. Mr. President of the Council, unfortunately, the terrorist events that have occurred since 2001, the latest events in
The India of these days, the various conflicts present in many parts of the world make this topic, the topic of arms trade, particularly important for the present and the future in a broad sense.
Often, too often, the praiseworthy intentions expressed at the level of declarations of principles do not then find concrete application in the facts.

It is clear to everyone that the argument is delicate, it involves important industrial and commercial processes and therefore it is understandable the difficulty of ratifying a control and regulation system on the part of all States, especially the Member States.

However, the string of events and the awareness that the internal and external trafficking of weapons in an illegal manner exists, pushes for the urgency of regulating this sector in a legally effective manner.
The directive currently being drafted on the intra-community transfer of goods related to defense will have a real meaning if the code of conduct is quickly ratified.
I am sorry that the President of the Council in charge has left, but after what he said, I will skip some other aspects I had prepared. After what he said, it seems that everything is fine.
Actually, I don’t think that’s the case. Absolutely not.
And so I believe that the commitment that the Minister has taken on this evening, like so many other commitments taken on by so many others in other circumstances, I believe that it can be...
to translate, in this final stretch of the French Presidency, into a deep stimulus also for next week, so that the Code of Conduct is ratified at least by all Member States.
It would be commendable if France did it, rather than just declaring it here in the Chamber and then maybe not having concrete results.
President, I believe that in these days we should realize more that when we talk about Tibet and the Dalai Lama, we are actually talking about ourselves.
A few days ago, at the simple announcement that the European President, President Sarkozy, dared to
In Poland, to meet the Dalai Lama, we were treated without even being given the eight days off, no meetings.
Why does the great Europe allow itself to welcome or to speak, to accept, to listen to the Dalai Lama?
I believe it is clear. We know that if the European people were asked as a European people, 80% would be in favor of the Dalai Lama.
The Italian language is a Romance language, and it is the official language of Italy, San Marino, Switzerland, and Vatican City. It is also spoken in some regions of Slovenia, Croatia, and France.
Those who maintain that the 2020 European Directive imposes too high costs on the economy of the European Union.
Among these is the Italian government, which has presented cost estimates that are almost double, without, however, providing convincing evidence.

However, similar positions underestimate the future price of fossil fuels and ignore the enormous advantages deriving from the rapid spread of renewable energy, for example the security of supply, but above all the creation of new jobs at a time of recession in which thousands of workers are expelled from the production processes.
The increase in energy efficiency and the widespread use of renewable sources are the recipe to get out of the economic crisis.
Focusing a large part of public funds on saving banks means to propose the same economic model, all based on finance, that created the crisis we are trying to fight.
The economic situation cannot be tackled without changes in strategy.
The EU directive aims at innovation and, above all, tries to tackle in time the upheavals created by the climate changes already in progress.
A problem that will weigh more and more on the lives of European citizens and on the economy of the Member States.
This is why public investments should not go, once again, to support traditional sectors, but should focus on activities that bring innovation in the energy and environmental fields.
Key factors for the growth of the renewable energy sector are the development of distribution networks and priority access to these networks.
Between the 60s and 80s, the huge expenses for network infrastructures, for the large centralized systems, were supported with large public investments.
This aspect must also be valid to ensure the future of the energy system based on renewable energy.
It is therefore necessary to manage renewable energy generation plants with new technologies. This is where investments, research and technology development are needed.
The urgency remains to approve this package in the first reading in the December plenary, as European citizens expect.
We cannot allow the myopia of the interests of some States and of some economic interests to block this process.
Thank you, President. For future memory, if the future will have a memory, we are witnessing a genetic change of that Parliament, of that European Union, President, that
In 1985 you got to know and contributed to making the European homeland live, against the fatal illusion of the old Europe of homelands.
Today we are going in that direction every day.
Yesterday, the day before yesterday, at the Council, the Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals was recalled, an old nationalist and not Europeanist memory.
The Europe of Cadenau Calergi, but also of Winston Churchill, of our names that give name to our Parliament.
They were for the United States of Europe. Today we only talk about partnerships to all those who instead want to be members, to be in Europe. And I believe that we are...
handing over the Mediterranean to a certainly dangerous sort and certainly striking the Europeans and the democrats of those countries.

The proposal of the Council, which at the time found a good balance, I think of the great work done in this sense by colleague Luigi Cocilovo, does not find our agreement, because it marks a clear setback.

Many points of the work-life balance, of the work-life relationship, of the work-guarantees relationship, and it is a choice that weakens the rights of workers, which are then the rights of all of us, of our children, of normal people.
I would not like this speech to be mistaken for a union or corporate one, because I am defending the healthcare personnel.
No, it’s not like that. As a politician, I don’t act on behalf of corporations or unions. I act on behalf of citizens.
I think of them when I make my choice, I think of their social rights which are fundamental to me in Europe.

I therefore do not believe that it is a good Europe, one that does not move forward while the world does, one that instead makes glaring mistakes in perspective, confusing the weakening of safeguards with flexibility and freedom.
This is all the more serious at a time when Europe is experiencing its worst crisis and does not see prospects for prosperity and growth.

If we do not understand, Mr. President, Council, Council representatives, Commission, if we do not understand that at this moment millions of workers are at risk of losing their jobs and feel in a state of weakness and precariousness,

and they certainly do not have the contractual and voluntary capacity, other than opt-out, then I must say that we are not aware of what is really happening in the social and family life of Europeans.
For this reason, we will support the proposals of the rapporteur Sergas and we hope that the whole Parliament will do so.
I must say that the Council's unavailability to negotiate at this stage forces us to obtain a place for discussion and negotiation in the conciliation venue.
Thank you, President. We are facing an important compromise for Europe, even if the European Parliament has had to swallow some bitter pills.
As for the merits, the text on renewable energy that came out of the trilogue contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of their mandatory nature.
The 2014 review clause is to be understood as a key to greater flexibility to focus on the reduction target that remains at 20% and, if the conditions are met, to push it up to 30% by 2020.

It should be emphasized that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility tool for Member States is in national measures of efficiency in the sectors of construction, transport, industry and in the better use of electricity.
The mandatory objective of 10% for biofuels must be qualified with efficiency requirements in the transformation processes, through the adoption of environmental and social sustainability criteria.
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas and towards more efficient conversion technologies than first and second generation biofuels.
The agreement reached by the Council and the will of the European Parliament send a positive message. It is not possible to face the very serious economic crisis without changes in strategy.
Those who, like Berlusconi, made fun of the European directives, the 320s, defining them as a Don Quixote plan, have been defeated.

The package that this Parliament is called upon to approve, despite the watering down due to the selfishness of the Member States, is aimed at providing innovative responses to alleviate the impact of climate change.
If we do not act quickly, this problem will weigh more heavily on the European economy, but above all on the lives of European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am very grateful first of all to the President of the Agriculture Commission of the European Parliament, colleague Parrish, for
having promoted this question after the important hearing of experts that we have carried out in the same commission.
It is undeniable that the Mediterranean diet is part of the historical and cultural heritage of our continent, as it is undeniable its health principle.
The same Commission, in the White Paper against Obesity, identified it as an absolutely suitable natural medicine.
The health benefits are scientifically proven and are very popular abroad, starting with the United States.
It therefore happens that the concept is broadened to the point of distorting the originality.
For this reason, the recognition by UNESCO sanctions a definition to protect this peculiarity. I would like to tell colleague Parrish that
Today, we are talking about the Mediterranean diet as a peculiarity of European gastronomic culture, but certainly not as the only peculiarity of European gastronomic richness.
Mr. Commissioner, you have kept the commitment of your predecessor to recognize the importance of this initiative, and I thank you for that.
He has pointed out that he has no decision-making power within the UNESCO procedure, however, I think that he will be able to express an opinion, a work.

One minute. President, let's start from a concept: the Mediterranean diet, as confirmed by numerous studies, favors the fight against obesity and cardiovascular diseases and is generally very positive for human health in many aspects.

But here the point is not to claim to impose the Mediterranean diet throughout the EU or to try to promote it over other food regimes that are better suited to climates and regions other than the Mediterranean.
We have the duty, however, to protect it, to define it in its contents and characteristics, to defend it from imitations and external contaminations that could damage its image and value.
It is therefore valued, like all other European cultural expressions that deserve to be defended and promoted globally.
It is a model that the world tries to copy, so it is important to specify its peculiarities and safeguard it, to avoid losing a completely European heritage in the sea of globalization.
Thank you, President, Honourable Colleagues, I sincerely appreciate the work of Colleague Lamperrus, with which I share a good part.
I agree, however I am puzzled about some aspects, perhaps due to excessive trust in the Commission’s assessments.
First of all, I think that the expected development of the demand for gas is reductive.
reductive. If that were the case, I fear a negative impact on the sources of funding for the projects.
As for the infrastructures, the related projects are at different stages of development.

Instead of redefining priorities in the abstract, with a serious lack of attention to the Mediterranean area, it is appropriate to re-evaluate them in terms of development times, financial structure, available supplies and the relationship between public support and private commitment.
The colleague then recommended diversifying sources and supply routes.
An example is the Southern Corridor.
On such issues, I believe a phased, programmatic approach is necessary.

In fact, in the first phase of the Caspian Sea, only Azerbaijani gas will be available, while access to other countries will be registered in the second phase, making the market more complex for political, regulatory and infrastructural reasons.
Such problems could be solved by the Commission's proposal for a Caspian Development Corporation, which is also intended to facilitate the development of the missing infrastructures.
Missing. Which penultimate aspect is there no doubt that solidarity mechanisms are fundamental for the energy policies of the Union, also in relation to the Treaty of Lisbon?
It is nevertheless appropriate that the feasibility of such measures avoids, in addition to possible distortions, excessively costly processes.

Lastly, external relations and an important objective, in addition to the role of the Energy Charter, is the expansion of energy commitments, particularly to transit countries, even in the field of renewable energy.

The crisis in the automotive sector has become a crisis of an entire sector, of the knock-on effect on other related sectors, of commercial networks and therefore of services, and has dramatic prospects in terms of employment.

I think that even the dramatic drop in these latest registrations, for this month it is said that for some member countries it is down 33%, down 20% etc., demonstrates that it is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector, it does not arise within the sector or within that company due to management errors.
It is a systemic crisis and as such it must be urgently and decisively addressed by the European institutions.
Some remedies seem to have been identified, but it is important to know how to implement them, with which resources and with which innovation prospects.
It is certainly necessary to support demand. Consumption is the only engine of recovery.

But while this response, supporting consumption, is being made, which is a medium-term response, I think we must say that immediate credit support is needed to resume production, pay for materials, support employment, even in the face of a drop in orders and demand.
So, the credit field, but we were saying that the how is important.
And I too here call for a stronger role for Europe. It is important that European institutions give a sign.

America is intervening, some European countries are doing so, I hope that my country will move from generic proposals to concrete initiatives, but I hope that there will be stronger European action in the recovery plan and also beyond the recovery plan.

I am relaunching because I think, and our Commissioner has said it in a way, that the destiny of the great European houses is a common destiny. The great European producers should not find competition within the market.

in the form of various forms of state aid or tax breaks, but they must find a strong, incisive and coordinated response from Europe, because the fate of the European car market is measured by the ability to face global competition together.

And there is the other point that was mentioned, as Sacconi said, and I repeat it, support should not be help or, worse, aid that leaves everything as it is, but an incentive for competitive capacity.
The future of the sector in terms of innovation, environmentally compatible production and also technologies that are more respectful of the environment and the safety of travellers and transport.
We are pleased with the new willingness of Belarus to cooperate with the European Union and with the international community.
We are very cautious with Lukashenko, but welcome a new course in this area.
We will not tire of stressing the need for a comprehensive and substantial change of pace in the context of respect for human rights.

On one point, I believe that the Commission could demand a clearer and more consistent behavior from MISC. I am referring to the situation of the children, tens of thousands of whom have been hosted for a few months in European families.
For several years, the Belarusian government has had absurd, sometimes incomprehensible behavior, often canceling the stays of minors at the last minute, mortifying the families.
host families and giving a new loud slap to the children who, often orphans and coming from very complicated family situations, have suffered from all this.
We are trying to reach a change of course as soon as possible.
Yes. Reading the text of this document, one gets the impression that whoever wrote it wants not an improvement but a worsening of relations between the European Union and Russia.
If this is Europe's goal, then this document is excellent. If it is not, then it is terrible.
I believe it is a very bad document.
How can we think of a future of new tensions with a country whose indispensability we recognize in our own interest?
In the next 40 years we will have to rely on traditional energy resources, of which Russia is rich. Could we do otherwise?
No.
Secondly, the manner and the tone. In these pages, Europe speaks in an imperial language, not the language of someone who respects their interlocutor.
This contradicts our own policy of good neighborliness and it would not be right to use it even against a small country, let alone against a large country that rightly claims to be respected.

It is a matter of realism, first and foremost. The European Parliament is about to approve, I fear, a document written in the spirit of the Cold War, old, useless, harmful, counterproductive, precisely at the moment when the new American President is coming to weave a new dialogue with Moscow.
With this approach, Europe cannot claim any leadership and I hope that the Commission will not accept these recommendations.
Thank you, President. I appreciate the rapporteur's proposal. However, this resolution makes too many references, not only in this point and in this note of the proposed oral amendment.

but in many other parts of the resolution it refers to all Member States for different reasons and it also refers to the same matter that you ask to be deleted from the note for the same matters in other parts of the resolution.

Therefore, Mr. President, I believe it would be appropriate for the colleague, and I propose this, to return, to ask that the resolution can be amended further and therefore return to the Commission to be re-examined.
What happened inside the Fiat here in Brussels?
Fiat has invented a kidnapping that never happened of its managers by the workers with the sole aim of decapitating the union.
There was no kidnapping on April 9th, nor ever.
The news was deliberately spread by Fiat in an attempt to discredit the workers who are defending their future against 24 dismissals.
Fiat refuses to have any meeting, any discussion, any negotiation with the union representatives.
The only objective is to fire 24 workers, 12 of whom are union representatives.
I believe it would be appropriate for Parliament to discuss not only this fact, but also the anti-union behavior and disrespect for workers' rights of Fiat and the
Many large European multinationals, which benefit from the rules and often from the subsidies of the national states and of the European Union, do not respect the rights of workers.
Thank you, President. Dear colleagues, I thank the Czech Presidency, the Commission, the President of the Energy and Industry Commission, Honourable Niebler, and the colleagues
The rapporteurs of this energy package, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission Secretariat with all its officials, for the collaboration and competence shown in this file.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved. I am, thinking of the effort made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with issues that were not easy to solve.

I am pleased to have coincided my second experience as a Member of the European Parliament with the final phase of this package, which I consider to be one of the most important dossiers of this legislature in favor of European citizens, our voters.
The Gas Directive, which will come into force from 2011, brings significant innovations to the sector. It is important to underline as a significant result the achievement of the option
which guarantees the opening of markets and a real progression towards a system that allows the European Union to truly speak with one voice on energy matters.
The Lito is the real novelty of this package and is the one on which it can be said that the European Parliament has had the best result.
The new gas directive gives great importance to the gas authorities and the agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, particularly in those countries where they must start their activities from scratch.

It is therefore of fundamental importance to have defined the role and competencies of these bodies, to have given them broad powers, since it is up to the authorities to carry out the difficult task of controlling the common energy market.
Another piece that was inserted during the trilogue phase is the exemption from common rules for so-called closed systems, i.e. airports, hospitals, stations, industrial sites, etc.
Their particular peculiarities are subject to a more favourable regime, and this is proof of the attention that the new directive gives to the needs of the European citizen.

The European citizen, in my opinion, is the one who will truly benefit from this directive, as by using smart meters he will have access to all the information related to the bill and will be able to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose his own supplier.

According to convenience. Because even if it is true that the effects of this liberalization will take years to be seen, it is undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to a reduction in prices and more favourable market conditions for the citizens of the Union.
Another important element is the recognition of European transmission network systems, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
All this also goes through the reinforcement and creation of new infrastructures, such as regasifiers and storage facilities, which will be the engine of the third package.
Therefore, it is necessary to open a competitive market that guarantees investments and long-term contracts by companies in the sector.
In particular, in the new Member States, where the creation of new infrastructures would also help to solve problems of age-old dependence.
The protection of the weakest consumer was taken into consideration, giving national and regional authorities the possibility of guaranteeing gas supply in the most critical moments.
The happy result of the gas directive and of the entire energy package once again highlights the role of Europe and its institutions for European citizens.

Today we are gathered here to defend a food, cultural and rural heritage that comes from a centuries-old tradition, an invaluable heritage that the world envies us, which represents an enormous wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks being in serious difficulty due to the will of the Commission and the Council to abolish the ban on blending for the production of rosé wines, a will born under strong pressure from the French government.

under pressure and that will be ratified without the possibility of intervention by Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, between producers and consumers, who will be affected by such an initiative.

The Commission proposes to allow rosé wines to be made simply by mixing red and white wines, as is done by countries that do not have our skills and professionalism, with the simple pretext of responding to international competition.

As a confirmation of the question, I would like to point out that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of tradition and research, of very important investments, of passion,
And attention to detail is not the answer we need, especially in a moment of economic crisis like this, in which the average consumer surely pays more attention to the price than to a label.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be enough to find a name for the new product and inform consumers of the existence of two different types of rosé, of the different quality of the products, of the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of the professionals in the sector.
Who will pay for all this?

Does the Commission envisage any support programme in this sense, or will the producers still have to pay, after having asked them to fight, with unequal weapons, low-cost competition in already very difficult times?
I hope that the Council Commission will make the right choice and, if necessary, review this procedure entirely.
Thank you. President, I would like to first greet the President of the EPP, Mr. Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the tribune of honor and who is following the debate.
Dear Ahmet, know that we are in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle that your party is leading in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize the DTP as an indispensable tool for the promotion of democracy in Turkey and for this reason we firmly condemn the police operations that the
Prime Minister Erdogan has ordered against you, imprisoning all three vice presidents of the HDP along with over 300 activists and sympathizers.
The victory of the DTP in the last local elections shows that the DTP is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has asked Prime Minister Erdogan to start direct discussions with the PKK, but instead his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more prison.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the left in Europe have so far supported the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, while at the same time supporting the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in the last two years, and especially in the last few months, Erdogan has shown another face, that of a leader committed to the worst part of the Turkish army, which simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds, and Erdogan himself is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is his and only his responsibility for what is happening in the Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of the European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority, which clearly involves direct negotiations with the PKK, or we will be forced to ask for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

The road to Turkey's accession to the Union goes through Diyarbakir and the DTP, otherwise we will be the ones, that is, those who have supported the accession process here, to ask for a pause for reflection that risks being definitive.

Thank you, President. I would like to thank the Council for sharing the principles and, above all, if I may, Commissioner Barro, with whom I had a very fruitful dialogue that was extremely useful in the work we then brought to the floor.

I would like to thank from the heart also the colleagues who worked on this report, giving me ideas and clearly bringing all their experience. First of all, colleague Demetriou, Baroness Ludford and the excellent President De Prie.
I would like to say that exactly what Demetriou, Latford and De Pre say is the most important thing, the challenge of the European Union, because achieving a unitary European judicial culture

Naturally, by waging a serious battle on what De Prè says, the independence of justice, the guarantees and smoothing out the disparities of the various judicial systems are the challenges that lie ahead.
But I believe that the work we have done allows us to be optimistic.
To the Honourable Romagnoli, I would like to say that, from my point of view, which should also be yours, there is certainly a pessimism for Italy, but we must have a...

The optimism of the will and the work that you, Honourable Romagnoli, have also done and the contribution you have made to the report means that all together we can build the European Union and the European Union is a reality also for us Italians.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, it seems that the thousands of deaths that have occurred so far due to asbestos, that the tens of thousands of
The people who risk dying in the next few years due to past exposure to asbestos - we know that the latency period can be as long as 15 or even 20 years - do not count for anything.
It seems that the Eternit process, which began in Turin, does not count for anything, regarding what happened in Casale Monferrato, where there is not a single family that has not suffered a loss.
Asbestos should have been banned by the Member States by applying Directive 99.

The States should have protected, with all possible precautions, the workers exposed, applying the 2003 Directive, closing the plants, carrying out the reclamation of the contaminated sites, compensating the victims and the populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Very little has been done.
I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian bosses are on trial.
Everyone knew, little was done, and it is especially the industry that has shirked its responsibilities, acting through the cracks in public authorities' inertia.
Examples of inertia are what is happening in Italy, in Brioni, where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Marghera, in Cengio, where there are still deaths.
Today the industry is asking the Commission to tolerate yet another derogation, already granted for a limited time, from the 2006 REACH regulation on chrysotile asbestos fibre.

It is true that low voltage electrolysis plants have a limited application and only in a few plants, but where industrialists claim that any alternative replacement would lead to the closure of the plants.

A blackmail, but alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, using technologies to replace asbestos-free membranes for low voltage and a similar solution has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why in some states yes and in others no?
Why, as in the long battle for the ban of PCB, have there been so many omissions and reticences, even supported by the DG Enterprise of the European Commission?
In this case too, the right example was not given.
The 1999 directive on the ban of asbestos required that the revision of such authorization be preceded by an opinion of the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never produced.
This is how the Commission respects the guidelines.
Not to mention the union, which says it was not even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to rely on the performance of others.

This resolution asks the Commission to fill, by 2009, a legislative gap on the ban of second-hand products containing asbestos, roofing sheets, aircraft parts and anything else that should be disposed of permanently.
Precise dates are set, once again, for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were objectives already written in 1999.
Ten years have passed and the deaths continue.
The UIL had claimed, among the first initiatives of this legislature, the establishment of a community fund to compensate the victims, ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today instead is bowing to the will of the multinationals.
Instead, it is necessary to move on to concrete commitments.
Only when they will start from the same requests of this resolution, only then will we be able to be understanding.
Today this intention is not clear, that is why we vote against the granting of the derogation.

Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express to President Buzek the pride that fills me at this moment in belonging to an important institution such as the European Parliament, which he presides over.

I believe that the sacrifices made in the last twenty years in his country, which today make him represent those twelve countries we were talking about earlier in this meeting, give strength to Europe.
However, I also want to express my concern after listening to your program within your speech, which should, and I hope it will, strengthen this Parliament.
I hope that what has been announced will be realized.
I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will listen to her for the strong words she has spoken, so that this Parliament can give more than 100 answers.

550 million citizens who in this Europe have voted for us, have wanted us and want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly tried to give, but has not been able to give completely.
I place my hopes in this activity and I am certain that with it we will be able to achieve the certainties that it has hosted.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and wanted this debate, to transfer to the European level the prerogatives of Italian internal policy.

The issue of freedom of information concerns all of us, it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level, in order to counter political and economic conditioning and to guarantee real pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous interweaving of media, political and economic powers.

It is precisely for this reason that we are asking for a European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italianism, serves to protect the plurality of information, avoiding concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to provide the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Thank you, President. I am aware that on September 30, the Commission presented a study on the media pluralism index in the Member States.
But in 2008 a report was voted on, rapporteur Marianne Mikko, with which the European Commission and Member States were invited to protect, I quote literally, the multiplicity of
to defend the plurality of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diversified information media.

And even earlier, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, rapporteur Bogart Quack, on the risks of violation in the European Union of the freedom of expression and information, with which the Commission was asked to present a communication on the guarantee of the pluralism of the media in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet given clear answers to the requests of the Parliament.

You will notice, Madam Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country nor my Prime Minister, but in this seat, as a European citizen, I ask you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you. I wanted to... I have seen the vote that took place yesterday in the Environment Commission being reported many times.
I would like it to be clear, however, that it cannot all be reduced to a single extremist ideological position.

We have heard many positions from our colleagues, which are very varied, more articulated, more sensible, and therefore, being more in line with reality, I believe they are more able to provide real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist. When this mistake was made of identifying a problem in such an ideological way, answers were not given, but...
Disasters, and Europe should be a master in this, not repeating the same mistakes even if in different clothes and with labels that seem apparently much more friendly.

I must remember that the same directive of the mission trading provides that the virtuous path of the European Union is subject to an evaluation by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
We must go to the conference with strong positions, with clear ideas, but absolutely trying to equitably divide the...
Efforts by all industrialized countries first and foremost, which must take on equivalent emission reduction targets, but also not forgetting what colleague Grostet reminded us of, that now

Among developing countries, we cannot fail to make some distinctions. There are truly developing countries, and there are countries that have already emerged, countries with economies that have already emerged, I am talking about India, China, Brazil.
These are countries that cannot fail to take on their commitments.

I, on the other hand, strongly ask that if there is no balance in Copenhagen, the European Union continues to ensure the granting of free quotas to sectors at risk, in the sense of Directive 2003/87/EC.

These are fundamental points, we want the Kyoto Protocol itself to maintain its environmental significance and we want above all that a financial bubble is not created to the detriment of our European companies.
It is very important for two reasons. The first is the topic of research, which concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and the second is the modality of joint programming in research.
We would obviously have preferred, and this was the subject of our question, a more direct participation of Parliament in the pilot project.

If we must not stop now and we must proceed, we ask for guarantees that our opinion is taken into account in the reception of the Competitiveness Council and that a more certain legal basis is clarified for the future for a full involvement of the Parliament and for a full ownership in this matter of research.

Now we must intervene with adequate means and resources to prevent and eradicate a widespread plague such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and other diseases that are destined to grow in the face of the aging population.
We ask that we focus on large-scale studies, both for diagnosis and for identifying treatments.

Research on biomarkers, early diagnosis methodologies based on a multidisciplinary approach, the creation of large databases, the search for curative drugs and appropriate care models and services seem to be fundamental.
I have only one request to make in this setting: do not overlook the subjectivity of patients, too often excluded in this type of disease, nor the involvement of patient and parent associations.
From a methodological point of view, we believe that joint research projects are very important because they meet a fundamental need, that of concentrating efforts and resources.
to overcome those fragmentations, those duplications and thus be able to create a critical mass sufficient to provide adequate results for this type of research.

If we consider that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts manage to invest tens of millions of euros, we realize how much we still have to do and how much we must do, converging on projects

shared on strategic lines and shared programs between the States and Europe and on common programs between public and private subjects, without neglecting that international framework that puts us in contact with the great scientific realities at the international level.
What are the innovations of the Stockholm Programme compared to the Hague Programme? A fair balance between rights and security and legal protection in the field, both criminal and civil.
Safety is a right. Not being attacked in the workplace, walking down the street without risking one’s life, not being the object of violence as a woman, not being exposed to acts of terrorism.
The States and Europe must guarantee security.
But a security action that lessens the guarantees of freedom is an action that denies certainty to the law, and therefore is a source of insecurity and barbarism.
Guantanamo
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Programme defines them as “detailed provisions”.

Today, a fair balance between the discipline of crime repression on the one hand and the daily life of citizens, their family, social, economic, work and study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
It was built within the States and in the community institutions.
European society is more united, mobility is more intense than one might think.
Mobility is now a right.
The borders between states are not impermeable walls, but rather nets through which society filters every day.
Stockholm is the institutional framework, judicial cooperation, mutual recognition. A European justice, the national one.
and that of the community, a European, national and community right, a European citizen, a European judge, that of the national and that of the community.

European rules are dictated by community regulations and by the case law of European courts, but they also come from the behavior of workers, companies, students, magistrates, even national ones, and European networks among justice operators.
Bottom-up, therefore, and this process from the bottom, the Stockholm program wants to support.
Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, united vote, which we have worked hard for.
The Council should respectfully take this into account.
Lisbon is not yet in effect, but it is there, very present.
Be ambitious, Council, Minister, make the most of what we have worked out here and of the wealth of requests that emerge from it.
Budget Control Committee, I must acknowledge the very important work done by the Commission, the excellent work of the rapporteur and I must also say the political cohesion.

This is because from the very beginning we wanted to send a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to ensure transparency, correctness and legality in the management of public funds and therefore in the verification of the budgets.
Significant steps forward have been made with the Council, which initially did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always wanted to demonstrate that it operates towards transparency and correctness.
Therefore, we expect further steps from this point of view, because obviously it is absolutely unacceptable, especially with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.
Lisbon, that the Parliament does not have information and news precisely to verify the budgets and public funds in the interest not only of the European Union but also of all the citizens of Europe.
Honourable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the peace process in the Middle East.
We have seen the smile of hope of the Palestinian representatives.

These have been intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children glued to the grates of the windows of their homes, on a street in Hebron, the ghost street that no Palestinian can cross.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman, evicted from her home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent set up in the garden of what had been her home. The suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built, with European funds, a factory that was then destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but the Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The decision of the Council of Europe is a significant step forward, but we must act immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the last day of the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the delegation of the European Parliament, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this issue the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, should intervene to make the protest of democratic Europe heard.

I would like to thank President De Rossi, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because during the days we spent in Palestine, the weak of Palestine were able to see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Thank you, President. The European Union is committed to fighting terrorism in all its dimensions.

When talking about the fight against terrorist crimes, it is necessary to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures adopted to combat terrorism are adequate and effective.

The rights of defense and the fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the institutions of the Union, even when they define lists of persons and entities, in this case linked to Al-Qaeda.
Al-Qaeda, subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures are subject to adequate democratic and parliamentary control, as the Lisbon Treaty rightly prescribes.

It is therefore evident that, as also stated by the Parliament's legal service, any measure of this type will have to follow the co-decision procedure, allowing the representatives of European citizens to fully perform their legislative and guarantee role.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our disagreement with the Iranian government.
I would like to point out, since it has not been mentioned here, the fact that is one of the most serious violations of civil rights, which is that against young people.
The Iranian government has signed the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, but it continues to impose the death penalty on minors.
I would like, after this debate, that on the one hand Baroness Ashton takes on the commitment to indicate a common line for all of Europe and for the entire European Parliament.

on the one hand, the European Union on the events in Iran and, on the other hand, that the Interparliamentary Commission with the Iranian Government take note that the course of action must be changed.

I participated with friends Scuria and Tattarella in the protest that we had formulated in front of the Commission, which, however, even with an official statement, declared that it wanted to go to Iran, having instead asked in a peremptory manner that there be the possibility of meeting the opposition and dialoguing with it.

I would like the Commission to turn the page from this moment on and to have relationships of help, support and confrontation with the representatives of the opposition who are in exile, not least Ms. Maryam Rajavi who represents this reality.
This is what the European Community should do, rather than sanctions.

Colleagues, I am speaking to highlight the seriousness of the deindustrialization situations that are affecting various industrial hubs in Sicily, particularly the automotive hub in Termini Imerese, belonging to the Fiat Group, and the petrochemical hub in Gela, belonging to the Eni Group.
The Imerese is damaged by the competition deriving from the system of low wages within some countries of the EU, but it freezes Asian competition.
With regard to the processes of severe deindustrialization that are occurring in the widespread areas of the Union, I believe that the time has come to reconsider the line of non-intervention.
The intervention so far adopted by the European Commission is to start to approve a package of measures in support of the relevant and strategic European industries.
The present exhortation is addressed especially to the European Commission and to the Commissioner for Industry, Tajani.

Thank you, Mr. President, honorable colleagues. The theme of fiscal good governance, although always of great importance, has assumed even greater relevance and prominence after the great economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International summits, the G20 and European ones in particular, have discussed and continue to discuss the issue, especially when dealing with the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All this is important, it is a sign of commitment and will, but we must not be under the illusion that an announcement is enough.
A serious and consistent policy is needed.
There are still many problems.
It is still too easy to buy or open a shell company to evade taxes.
Just take a look on the Internet. There are thousands of websites offering companies for sale, even in countries of the European Union.
And often, an email with a scanned copy of the passport attached is enough to open a company.
We must put an end to the practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation.
This report that I am presenting is based on the communication of the European Commission on fiscal good governance of 28 April 2009.
The report aims to advance concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The fight against tax havens, tax evasion and illicit capital flight must be considered a priority for the European Union.
From this comes the principle of good governance, which is based on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation, and fair competition.
The point is that there is a need for ever greater cooperation and collaboration in fiscal matters in the European Union.
The general objective that we must set ourselves is to achieve an automatic exchange of information on a global and multilateral scale, obviously starting from the European Union.
As colleague Alvarez has already said, we must completely abolish bank secrecy in European Union countries, and put an end without further delay to the regime of tax havens.
a temporary measure that authorises the application of withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in place of the exchange of information.
I do not want to dwell on the concrete proposals contained in the report.
I would like to point out that we still need some specific points: extending the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, fighting VAT fraud, establishing a public register of the Union.
that takes into account people or companies that have created companies or opened accounts in tax havens. To reconfirm and relaunch projects for tax harmonization, starting with

It is also necessary for the European Union to speak with one voice on the international stage, to fight for the improvement of the OECD's rules to achieve automatic information exchange instead of information exchange upon request.

Commissioner Kovac, you have also heard the other reports. We need a strong commitment from the Commission and we need, at this moment, for these priorities to be highlighted to the new Commission at the time of the handover.
We will ask the Council and the Commission to account for their work.
like the European Parliament. I thank my colleagues and especially the shadow rapporteurs for the contribution they have made to this work, which I hope will be approved by the Parliament.

One minute. I must admit that when we talk about the fight against terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are not examining the issue adequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Isn’t it time to tackle the problem of terrorism by getting to the heart of the matter, rather than just limiting ourselves to its external phenomenology?

Addressing the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also the direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I ask myself and I ask this Parliament: do we want to discuss terrorism?
So, let this Parliament have the courage to face a political debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and on the propensity to share Western values, rights and freedoms.
To this end, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full veil, to encourage this Assembly to openly address the issue.
It seems that there is no will to address the issue.
I ask myself and I ask you, honorable colleagues of all political groups, if not on these issues, on which others should the political voice of the peoples of Europe be heard?

Thank you, President. The closure of the negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a possible objective, and the Svoboda report highlights in a balanced way the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is justice, the sector in which incisive reforms are still needed.
It is not enough, in fact, to complete the necessary system reforms and approve new laws and cooperate as necessary with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a true legal culture and mentality in line with European standards.
The independence of the judiciary becomes crucial, a central issue, the training, recruitment and career of judges, the absence of various types of conditioning exercised by the government on judges.
I call on the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this sense during the final phase of the negotiations.

Thank you, President. Croatia's accession to the European Union strengthens the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe, without obscuring, but rather integrating the specificities of its many souls.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in meeting the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Other steps forward can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to harmonize with what is provided for in the First Protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed in Paris in 1952, evaluating the restitution to the legitimate owners of the nationalized assets.
President, once again recently in Italy there was an environmental disaster, the Lambro river and the Po river.

Recently, the Court of Justice of Luxembourg has condemned Italy for the danger to which it exposed public health due to illegal waste disposal and for not being able to control waste collection in Campania.
The news of these days is about the increase in leukemia in Taranto through ILVA, as well as the disposal of asbestos in schools in Crotone, as well as dioxin in Campania.
It is a continuous environmental disaster.

I firmly ask the Commission what it intends to do to bring the Italian Government up to the standards of the European Union Directives, with particular regard to the ruling of the other day by the Court of Justice.
The Court of Justice has harshly condemned Italy for its failure to dispose of waste in Campania. The city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and months all over the world.

This debate is not a ritual, but it wants to be very concrete and ask clear and precise questions: how many resources, where to get them from? And I hope, the Parliament hopes, that the answers will be just as clear and precise today and in the next Councils on the 12th and 25th of March.

We want to firmly tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against emissions in the atmosphere, of the climate challenge, today has the duty of coherence if it does not want to lose credibility.
It must do everything possible to ensure that these objectives are met.

We must be very aware that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system. It means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential for our production system, for the European industry to remain competitive.
I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligence is ready, the skills are there, the will is there, now it is a matter of starting this engine.
The Commissioner said it, the Council said it, the Member States must do it, the entrepreneurs, the private forces.
But I believe that the essential task of putting together this complex partnership is that of the European Union.
To address the employment issue in a constructive way, the three key words in community relations are: react, evolve, protect.

React, that is, abandon the celebratory tones of Euro-propaganda to tackle in a concrete way the problems that afflict the citizens of the EU, ensuring a direct connection between the world of training and the needs of the market and the territory, requalifying among young people the perception of manual professions.

To evolve, that is, to make the UE 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the requests of companies and those of workers, in favor of a labor market in which the flexibility of contractual forms responds to the instability of market demand.

To protect, that is, to give work to those who have lost it, first of all to our citizens. Member States must therefore evaluate immigration policies based on real immigration needs. And with 23 million unemployed, it would be necessary to evaluate the possibility of blocking extra-community immigration for a few years.
I don’t see any other way to protect our work and our social system.
We need concreteness, courage and decentralization.
Mr. President, this is an oral amendment to point 13, which invites the Commission to verify, in the current situation, the possibility of providing humanitarian aid, verified the situation.

Luigi De Magistris, please. Yes, President, I would like to emphasize once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other MEPs and that more than half of the European Parliament has approved, in order to commit the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on the issue of corruption.

I have just returned from a visit to Greece on behalf of the Budget Control Committee, and one of the reasons for the structural crisis in Greece is certainly the waste of public money, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Eaten away by corruption, as is emerging in these days, corruption that mainly revolves around the illegal management of public money, the relationship between a part of politics and a part of entrepreneurs and the organized crime of white collars.

It is important that the European Parliament exerts all its pressure on the Commission, on the Member States, that Member States that do not comply are sanctioned and that the European institutions that must control corruption and the fight against organized crime are strengthened.
We know that the difference between male and female is even more marked in the field of self-employment.
In fact, women are often forced to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of assuming the role and the work load that comes from the absolute dedication to the family.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to adopt measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but always keeping the family in mind. Only this can give meaning and hope of success to these same measures.

Freeing women from the anguishing dilemma of choosing between the role of mother, wife and entrepreneur means making the burden of family work less onerous and tackling concrete problems through positive and specific measures to support the family.
Putting the family at the centre, otherwise any package of measures will be a set of uncoordinated interventions, ultimately useless.

Thank you, Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner. Today we are discussing organ transplantation, which certainly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare field.
but on the other hand it opens up a whole series of problems regarding the rights of the donor and the patient, which need to be addressed on an ethical, social, legal and economic level.

It is a matter of activating a virtuous path that addresses the serious imbalance between needs and the quantity of available organs, without however harming the principle of free and voluntary donation, thus preventing any...
Every form of commercialization and illegal trafficking, guaranteeing the quality and safety of organs intended for transplants, with measures that can combine confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, such objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
To this end, I believe it would be very important to establish a European data bank and adopt common quality and safety standards.
However, we must be careful not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create further bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done correctly and effectively.
It would not only be contrary to our objectives, but...
Thank you, President. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on the adoption of the European Union's accession to the Convention on Human Rights.

It represents a benefit for European citizens because it will create a new court outside the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and the Member States.

In virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and the Member States must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is essential that every nation that adheres to the Convention must have a judge who explains the context of each appeal. Just as I consider it important

That the European Parliament has an informal body with the aim of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council. It is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, as well as the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is essential that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider the development of guidelines with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that accession will entail.
Thank you, President. 170 measures in 5 years, numbers that are too ambitious for a program that lacks a real connotation, especially on some topics.
On immigration, the programme, beyond the official documents, shows an embarrassing weakness. What is the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if there is no political strategy?

A strategy that is truly useful and must be based on some firm points: fighting illegal immigration along the southern border, sharing with all European states and the Ionians the fight against illegal immigration, a policy of agreements with third countries and, above all, the recognition that immigration, at the moment of the crisis, is not a resource.
From the Parliament's homepage we read that more than 20% of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed, the Commissioner for Home Affairs says that the issue of immigration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, we need to think with concreteness and realism. Today the priority is to give work to our citizens. Everything else is do-gooder rhetoric that does not help either the integration of immigrants or our people.
President, I apologize, I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Presidency to intervene because the connections are...
That flights between Strasbourg and European capitals are direct and do not continue to cause inconvenience to those who have to take 3-4 flights to get to Strasbourg.
I ask you to intervene appropriately.

The financial situation of these months and years, the new Lisbon Treaty with its new tasks, the challenge we have set ourselves with Europe 2020, require the mobilization of new and substantial financial resources.
The paradox we are witnessing even in this discussion is that, at the current state, both the Commission and the Council appear silent to us, unable to choose and make decisions.
However, we know that if we want to get out of the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to tackle the major environmental, development, cohesion policy and
In the coming years, we need to invest more in Europe and in the function of Europe, and therefore in the essential function of Europe, that is, in its budget.
For this reason, we should not be afraid to discuss, even in a phase of financial resource scarcity, investing more in resources.
having the strength and ability to develop a debate and a confrontation that puts the issue of more resources also on the issue of more quality and more flexibility in their use.
And this is the challenge that lies ahead of us.
Yes, thank you Mr. President. Honourable colleagues, the European Parliament is called, as we know, to express itself definitively on consumer food information.
It must be said immediately that it was an objectively laborious, long and controversial legislative process that could not be shortened.

In fact, it is a matter of harmonizing the Community law on food through regulations and acts that make information transparent to consumers, avoiding leading them to make confused or potentially harmful choices, even for their health.

The report by the Honourable Sommer, to whom we must acknowledge the effort made to synthesize multiple requirements, with the aim of remedying the controversies and different information systems existing in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to date differ in the denominations of the nature of foods put on sale, generating a different system from country to country, feeding also unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.

Thus, based on the proposal of the European Commission, an attempt was made to give a new look to the legislation in force, involving on the one hand the food industries and on the other the consumers.
In this context, the report calls on the European food industry to clarify the mandatory indications, the indication and presentation of nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not exempt itself from adequately innovating the legislation of its food products, in order to better protect food trade, safeguarding it from increasingly invasive and wild international competition.

It is not new that we hear more and more often about the proliferation of food products that, on their labels, make claims and provide indications that often do not meet the nutritional requirements, but are still marketed as beneficial foods for human health.
Madam Commissioner, we wanted this oral question and a parliamentary resolution to clarify with the Commission that
Within the Stockholm Programme, it is very important to build a European legal culture, widespread in our territory.

And I would like to say immediately that this is important, but also that, in view of the communication that the Commission will have to produce on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify some concepts.
First of all, that the consultations start soon, the consultations of the Parliament, and that they come in the initial phase, when one begins to design the idea.
of these future projects, so that we do not arrive too late, when the projects are already formulated in a sufficiently detailed manner.
I say this because we have some fundamental observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of the individual states, is today a decisive piece for the construction of Europe,
Because by interpreting national rights in a European key, it provides the conditions to resolve conflicts and regulate the daily life of citizens.
And thus the European citizenship is founded, thus a European sensitivity is founded for all those who live in these territories, so that they can touch with their own hands
The advantages that the introduction of European elements in all the rights of the States, and therefore especially of Community law, makes citizens live better.
They offer real advantages to address a series of problems that would otherwise remain unsolved.
And I would like to say with this that we would like to turn the approach around a bit.
For example, we would not agree that these projects should be like Erasmus, because the number of magistrates and lawyers involved in projects like Erasmus would be
very low, as it cannot be otherwise, due to the high costs of physical mobility in this field, and therefore not very relevant in the overall context of the judiciary.
But the most important question concerns the term “familiarization” of the courses that we have introduced in our document.

Judges are not schoolchildren sitting in a classroom to whom lessons are given. They are mature people with a high level of professionalism, with little time available for this, not easily movable, but they bring...

knowledge in itself, and they must be encouraged to measure their knowledge against the new problems of European law and culture, creating conditions for exchange that are predominantly virtual rather than physical.

physical, using technologies, the network and the various opportunities that can determine these exchanges, starting not so much from a general approach, but from individual cases, from individual problems that judges and lawyers find themselves facing.
which are new and which must stimulate a professional growth of these legal operators within an effective stimulus to
contribute to the autobiographical reflection of their experience, of what they have learned to respond to the challenges that Europe is presenting in positive terms.
