As you can see, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, we intend to put something new in the tradition of the courses that have been done so far and that seem to us to be scarcely effective for this purpose.

We need to know how much funding is available and what kind, and express a doubt about the idea, as written in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process, because we are in favor of a bottom-up movement and not centralization.
It is a new setting.

What we want to convey, however, is that if we do not foster a European mindset among judges and lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who request it, we will not build Europe.
So this is not only an important card for European justice, it is an important card for the whole development of European unity.
Thank you, President. The proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, in particular the disabled or those with reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should guarantee passengers, as happens in the railway and air sectors.
The position in second reading is aimed at establishing a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus.

I agree with the rapporteur Cancian’s line and thank him for the excellent work done. I believe that the scope of the regulation should be modified, excluding regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be fair and appropriate to guarantee the rights of passengers in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as had already been decided in the first reading by Parliament.

The issue of information on passenger rights is equally important. It would be useful to provide passengers with information on connections with other means of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between bus passenger transport services and those by rail.

As far as disabled people and people with reduced mobility are concerned, it is necessary to ensure the maximum protection. I would propose a deadline of 24 hours instead of 48, in order to request assistance, as well as greater guarantees for the reimbursement and replacement of the instruments that ensure the mobility of people with disabilities in case of loss or damage.
Moreover, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructures improved to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, to promote intermodality, but above all to improve the travel conditions of passengers.

Thank you, President. I would like to thank rapporteur Sterckx for the excellent work he has done on this report, which deals with extending free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share the rapporteur’s view on the purpose of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime cargo transport within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate in a satisfactory manner, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the entire European maritime space, without borders, to make sea freight transport more attractive and optimally used.

The harmonization of administrative procedures among Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost maritime trade, which today represents less than 10% of the total.
To this day, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities that are imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore be activated as soon as possible, as this would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Moreover, interoperability is important to have real administrative simplification. In fact, the sending of information via e-mail is not at all efficient, it is useless if the information systems are not interoperable from a technical point of view.
As far as language is concerned, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
In this way, communication would be faster, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.
Yes, thank you, President. I would like to congratulate our rapporteur, Hon. Kramer, because we all know that we have achieved a result that sometimes seemed impossible.
I would like to recall that this directive, this file was considered a file at risk of conciliation procedure.
So, we have heard from the Commissioner's words, it is evident to everyone that we are facing a complex job that has taken a lot of time.
Just think, a directive from 1996, and this work brings us to the fifth and most important modification of the industrial emissions directive.
Just these few data, I believe, tell us by themselves of all the shortcomings and also the defects of this regulation.

A directive that is difficult to implement, I would like to remind you that nine Member States are subject to infringement procedures, and with such a wide scope of application that it is sometimes even inappropriate.

All this, we must not hide it, has required great efforts, it has required sacrifices from all the institutions involved, from all the political groups, from all the national delegations and it has often put us in front of really difficult choices.
I am here tonight to say with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results, protecting competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
We really have, on the one hand, a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, a directive that also allows the flexibility that is necessary.

I truly hope that the results of this merger will be, in the short term, a reduction in administrative burdens and, in the medium term, an improvement in environmental performance and a strengthening of the European industry.
Yes, thank you Mr. President. I would like to highlight the situation in which the Church is faced with a reality that for too long has not been given the importance it deserved.

That is to say, the instability in the scientific field in Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, are proving to be particularly fragile.

In the last month, Kyrgyzstan has suffered very harsh clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of inter-ethnic hatreds that will make the stabilization of the country even more difficult than it was before.

The task of the international community and of the European Union in particular, as has already been said, is to assist Kyrgyzstan as much as possible in three areas: by providing immediate aid for the
Emergency supplies and the reconstruction of destroyed homes. Second, through the longest possible economic aid, because, as far as the European Union is concerned, in the framework of the
Strategy for the Central Area and the tools implemented in this context, through political support for the process of returning to constitutional legality and the realisation of a true rule of law.
The constitutional referendum held in the crisis on June 28, in obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road to a return to constitutional order.

The electoral process of June 28, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation mission, which obviously took into account the special conditions in which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional order of Ecuador will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than a presidential one.

This will perhaps allow for a better consideration of the country's varied ethnic composition and the need to gather the consent of the various components of a country that is so fragmented and composite.
The European Union and Kyrgyzstan are linked by a partnership and cooperation agreement, which provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation commission.
It is our hope that our inter-parliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a Parliament that is democratically elected.
In the immediate future, the crisis, as already said, needs stability and our political and economic support. Let us try not to be stingy with either.
The European Council, where no one voted. Today we also have a rotating presidency in the hands of a government that has been disavowed by its own citizens.
This would be enough to understand why Europe is experiencing a deep crisis, a Europe that is now a political paradox in the hands of a political elite that citizens do not recognize.
The programme of the Belgian non-presidency talks about structural reforms, growth of employment, financial stability and competitiveness and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
However, the current crisis should push Europe towards ingredients that are very different from those that led to failure.
A general rethinking is necessary, because the crisis is not the mirror of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that Europropaganda would like to offer as a cure.
Today Europe is a huge building that is collapsing under the weight of democracy, centralism and the obstacles to free enterprise.
To get out of the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more concreteness, attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only accelerate the inevitable decline.
Mr. President, I thank you and apologize. I would like to emphasize in my speech how the progressive erosion of the income of European farmers, to the detriment of growing
The profit margins of the agribusiness sector are creating a worrying economic marginalization of those working in the agricultural sector, with consequent abandonment of the same activities.
Therefore, a change of course is required, which the European Commission itself recognizes and which the report to be examined in the Chamber this morning
The approval of the resolution this morning, which I wish to support, underlines with broad motivations and suggestions also of a legislative and compartmental nature.
It is necessary, in fact, to fight against global speculation on raw materials and to guarantee the security of supplies.

Moreover, better price transparency must be guaranteed, which not only does justice to the dignity of farmers, but also corrects the strong discrepancies existing in terms of bargaining power and abuses among the various operators.
Agriculture must be reaffirmed as a sector of economic and social stability and must regain its power in the commercial context of the European Union.
Immobilism and myopia, this is the diagnosis of the malaise that is affecting Europe 27 today.

Immobilism because in Italy one in four young people is unemployed and in the Eurozone there are 16 million unemployed, and also because the Euro propaganda of the last few months has not been followed by any concrete effective action.

Myopia because Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, not only has represented the usual recipe, but has completely lost sight of the more authentically territorial dimension of the policy of economic and social cohesion.

Only by putting the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting the peculiar cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment restart, nourishing themselves with the natural energies that each geographical area expresses, districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local bodies, favour subsidiarity, protecting a heritage made up of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the compass of the European Union does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Euro project is a certainty.
Mr. President, in the construction of a Europe of rights, a central place is held by the freedom of information, the plurality of information, the independence of information.

The Commissioner, Sir, the Commissioner, Madam, has noticed that there is a country in the European Union, which is also a founding member of the European Union with the Treaty of Rome, where there is no...
Is there any information pluralism when the Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the press?
What kind of democratic electoral competition can there be in a country where a Prime Minister and a political party control the media?
What kind of democracy can there be in a country where they want to pass a law that does not allow journalists to publish facts of judicial chronicles?
Other than Watergate, other than the regime's mouthpiece, the lapdog, what democratic country is it where they want to put the Internet under control?
What democratic country is it where those who go against the single thought are put in a corner and the free expression of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bokassa, nor the Romania of Ceausescu, nor the Italy of Berlusconi, where unfortunately this happens, also because the European Commission does not have the courage to express an autonomous and free position with respect to the Member States.
One minute to the Honourable Serracchiani. The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be...

It would be appropriate for the Commission to carry out an impact assessment, as some of my colleagues who spoke before me have recalled, of the opening of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the rights of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountainous or rural areas, so that they can receive mail regularly, and what tools does the Commission intend to adopt to make this happen?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must apply the directive and they all have the tools to do so.
Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues. The debate today on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that one part of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has told us very little about it, despite the fact that the Lisbon Treaty requires the Commission itself to promptly inform the Parliament.
As is known, Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it shown, to date, that it is willing to adopt behaviour in line with international law.

I am thinking of the case of Eritrean immigrants, held in an inhuman way in the Libyan center of Brak, or even the closure of the UNHCR offices. But I am thinking above all of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic speedboat opened fire.

against an Italian fishing boat from the Marina di Mazara del Vallo, present in international waters, with the justification of the presence on board of illegal immigrants. A very serious justification that makes us think that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy, which

It provides, among other things, for the repatriation of immigrants to Libya without provisions relating to the right to request asylum and to individual examination of the specific situations, and it also includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Since even in this case part of the agreement is secret, I ask if the Commission is aware of the content, if it does not consider it necessary in the specific case to ask for explanations on the merits.
The possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on boats if they suspect they are carrying irregular immigrants, because if this were the case, the provisions

On the economic level, it is positive for Europe to deepen trade relations with neighboring countries that are experiencing strong growth. However, the EU has always conducted, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries taking into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must therefore enforce these clauses with firm determination towards Turkey, a country that is re-Islamizing and where the condition of women is increasingly worsening, with more than 1,500
Women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence. A country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists, as in the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovese.

In the report, the Parliament encourages Turkey to take on a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is seeking to carve out for itself in the Arab world and in the

The friendship that Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups such as Hamas. In any case, if it is trade policy, so be it, but this must never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey’s entry into Europe.
Mr. President, Honourable Colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, with this measure we want to strengthen and rationalise the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious objectives that the relations in Mecheva set, modifying respectively Regulation 726 and Directive 2001/83.
Thanks to a close and efficient work of coordination between the Council and the European Parliament and the same parliamentary committees competent for the matter, it was possible to...
We are here today to discuss a proposal aimed at improving the community pharmacovigilance system and at perfecting the consistent and long-standing activity of the European Union in this sector.

Simplification, transparency and rationalization can be considered the key points of these two relations, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health, based on harmonized standards throughout Europe.

In fact, reference is made to a wide range of interventions that go from a better definition of the roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational subjects involved, to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient, to whom

It recognizes a key role in the system for strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicines, for simplifying communication activities, registration and evaluation of suspected adverse effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system must be improved, also thanks to closer collaboration at European, national and regional level.
Effective participation at all three levels will in fact ensure a profitable exchange of information regarding the side effects of medicines.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information in favor of patients, the national authorities and healthcare operators.
Thank you, Mr. President. It is precisely in these days that the operations have been carried out here in Brussels.

Many representatives of municipalities and regions have discussed how to tackle the serious problems that affect the life of our cities, the old and new needs that concern workers, families and small and large productive companies.
The economic crisis that has hit our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has been, on many occasions, the only concrete tool in the hands of the territories to try to provide some answers.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, for all regions, an essential lever for the process of European integration.
Now we find ourselves redefining this policy for the post-2013 period. We are therefore at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid some risks.
The first fundamental aspect is that of its renationalization. It would be a serious step backwards.

Then, it is necessary to ensure, in the construction of the financing budget, an adequate instance both for what concerns the weaker realities and for what concerns, at the same time, the capacity not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to make more compelling the ability to sanction those who have not.
We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
Honourable colleagues, the road to a Europe for women is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak for themselves: the global crisis has hit the labour market hard, putting female employment to the test, which in 2008 fell by a further 0.7 percentage points.

Despite the provocations that, in terms of equal opportunities and employment, periodically fill a propaganda that is in need of consensus, to date no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women a true realization as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not simply change its label periodically.

The directive that aligns the maternity leave institute in Europe is therefore good, but it is inefficient to deal with the complementary and equally important issue of paternity leave on the margins of this matter, in the same report.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic objective for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.
Thank you, I start again, thank you President. So, the rapporteur of the Development Commission, Honourable Mitchell, asked me to replace him because he cannot be present today.

I thank you for the work done with your usual, I must say, punctuality and for the quality of your proposals, which have received the favorable, I would say unanimous, opinion of the Development Commission.
Based on what I will say, but above all on what colleague Michel has done so far, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a large majority.
But now I come to the relationship.
In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905/2006, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had asked Parliament to approve an amendment that would allow non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
Proposal made by us accepted.
But the regulation on cooperation and development also contains the rules for implementing the European Union's development policy.
These rules provide that when the Commission has to adopt funding, it must follow the comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, in the event that the Commission oversteps its authority, Parliament can then adopt resolutions to ask the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Since 2006, the Parliament has considered that in at least 12 cases the Commission has exceeded its executive powers, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its decision proposal.
After the Lisbon Treaty came into force, the Development Commission proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic decisions on funding that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more relevant role.
In fact, according to the Treaty of Lisbon, in some well-defined cases, Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions. But what could these decisions be?
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

It is a choice that is up to the legislator. And then, which sectors should be given priority in funding? Education? Health? Environmental protection? Good governance capacity? Small business development?
And how can we ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices, the areas in which the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
It is here that the legislator must give precise indications to the executive.
And this is precisely the direction in which, I believe, the requests of European citizens are finally heading.
I really hope that there will be the greatest possible consensus for this report by Honourable Mitchell.
To the rapporteur. On the policy

In order to overcome the phase of good intentions and give a new impetus to a strategy that will represent a growth and development engine for the European Union, it is necessary to fill the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, in the fight against climate change and against pollution.
This very morning our colleague Pirillo reminded Parliament of yet another catastrophic event that occurred in the days past in the city of Paola, in Calabria.

The Commission will have to prove its concreteness, operating not only with the instruments of governance, but also by taking specific legislative measures, drawing the due lessons from the errors of the past, due to an approach that was often too sectorial.

We are fully aware that this process is very complex, but we are in the middle of a difficult and demanding crossing, which cannot tolerate any lack of attention and which needs adequate investments and

Participatory governance mechanisms, both at the institutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out for the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will be essential to consider the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage of all the riparian states, based on the principle of

Otherwise, the increasingly widespread practice of the unilateral declaration of exclusive or similar economic zones in the Mediterranean Sea, besides not being in line with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the idea of effective and shared governance.

I would like to remind you that only a month ago, this interpretation by Libya led to an armed assault on a European fishing vessel, and it would be wrong to claim that this is an exclusively Italian-Libyan matter.

Thank you, President. I would like to thank Hon. Meissner for the report on the integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding and to protect coastal regions, as well as to promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial field.
For this reason, cooperation between small and large ports that face the same sea basin should be encouraged, as this can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Moreover, to ensure intermodality, it is necessary to invest in port and hinterland infrastructures, i.e. ports that can be connected to the European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely that of port security.

It is necessary that there is a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and to avoid unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, instead, to guarantee greater security, must face higher costs.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thirty years ago, Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people. Today, it is denying that there is disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in the West Bank there are dead and wounded among a population that only claims the right to live freely in their own land.
Morocco has essentially closed its borders to anyone who could be a witness to these events.
No information and no deputies.
A French deputy and our colleague Meyer were denied access.
Europe is passively watching.
There is no sign of the Commission's communication that makes us subservient to the UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has done for the last thirty years.
There is no position taken by Ms. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
It is necessary to react with a position taken by Parliament.
It is necessary to react against Morocco, interrupting every initiative on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of the fishing agreements.

Thank you, President. My intervention does not want to be the usual rhetorical and oroscettic exercise, but an impulse so that the EU begins to pay more attention to the content than to the container, and abandons propaganda in favor of concreteness.
The Lisbon strategy having failed, Europe has come up with a new slogan, Europe 2020, but in fact it has not given any innovative response to employment problems.

The data confirms it: 9.6% is the unemployment rate in Europe, 20.2% is the youth rate. In Italy, the third net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young people without a job.

In the Europe I would like, there are no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but efficient investments so that the training offer prepares professionals for the sectors of the internal market, where there are concrete job opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our territories.
The world of craftsmanship offers employment potential and a unique heritage of knowledge, which must be entrusted with the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam President of the Council. The European will to set ambitious goals in view of the next climate change conference is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The international negotiations at the Cancun Conference, as far as we know, not only failed to make appreciable progress towards a global agreement, but also confirmed the mistrust and resistance to the commitments made in Copenhagen.
China has already been mentioned, but I would like to mention it here as well.
China, for example, is granted an increase in its emissions of 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset
and perhaps even less, but an attempt at compensation only with a 100% reduction of European industrial emissions within the same year, within 2020.

This data not only makes the proposal for an unconditional 30% reduction, which we strongly oppose, seem futile, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions for that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at least reckless and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and to outline suggestive but unrealistic scenarios, where the unknowns inevitably reflect on the dimension of costs.

The hope is that the European Union will bring to Cancun a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal, because it is always and in any case preferable an agreement that gives concrete and perceptible results rather than...

expectations inevitably doomed to failure and to make the efforts of governments on major environmental issues increasingly less credible in the eyes of international public opinion, and this would be a hardly reparable damage.

Thank you, Mr. President. I have only one regret in this room tonight, that we are discussing the Sahrawis only because the Moroccans have invaded the Tindouf camps and the UN. And this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
The Parliament should have developed the will to discuss this issue on its own, which has been rotting on international tables for 30 years.
This is the most relevant political data.
We were forced to commit acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to guarantee human rights.
What is it, if not respect for human rights, the fact that there should be a referendum for self-determination there?
It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong part of the relations. We must ask with force and with all the consequent acts that there is a no longer postponable will.
We must try to create the conditions so that the Minurso mission, which is closed, Mr. President, is not alone in creating the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must try to use all the means available to the European Union to condition this event and to ensure that the referendum does justice to 30 years of suffering of a people.
Mr. President, aside from this issue, I wanted to raise a problem with the Presidency.
I believe that some people still do not fully understand the role of the European Parliament after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am forced to raise a fundamental issue here. Commissioner Callas for Transport has repeatedly refused to meet with the Sky and Space Board to discuss the CESAR project, which is of interest to everyone from an economic, environmental and safety perspective.

I invite the Presidency to call Commissioner Callas to the floor and to explain what the program is that he intends to carry forward in this sector which is very delicate and important for the European Parliament.

Colleagues, the report and discussion certainly contain positive elements. The general orientation is towards simplifying procedures and streamlining bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with a regular residence permit in a Member State.

However, as a point of reflection, I would like to recall that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, many of them young, are unemployed due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and as a result of a crisis that does not seem to end.

Before anything else, for the citizens of third countries who live in our countries, it is the case that Europe should commit itself especially to implementing economic, political and social measures that help, above all, our citizens to find or find again work.
If Europe can provide jobs for its citizens, it will create solid social bases to adequately welcome migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, above all, to make Europe stand on its own two feet and with its own strength.

Thank you, President. To date, access to employment is regulated only for some specific categories of citizens of third countries.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must act to ensure equal treatment for both citizens of third countries who are legally residing in the Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or international protection, in accordance with Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to avoid a growing demand for seasonal workers, for example, simply because they are paid less or because they have lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinationals will move their headquarters to countries such as Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in their European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment for European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and self-employed workers are included in this directive.
Making a difference will become extremely dangerous.

Thank you, President. Honourable colleagues, human trafficking, according to estimates by international organizations and law enforcement agencies, is now the second most profitable source of income for organized crime worldwide, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that around 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution and forced labour.
This means that, above all, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against clandestinity, against crime that generates crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various ways.

In the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between Member States and between police forces is necessary, but above all, certainty of punishment for traffickers. However, let us remember that many people are

They are exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and desperation, and are ready to do anything to leave their land in the hope of a better life that will not be fulfilled.

Europe, therefore, in addition to crime prevention and the protection of victims of trafficking, must commit itself more and with greater scrupulousness so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
acceptable. Let us help them in their own countries. This must be the guiding principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed not only to repression, but also to prevention.

Thank you, President. Lady Ashton, honourable colleagues, as Vice-President of the Development Commission, I am committed to the problems of many countries, especially in the African area, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, if not even forgotten.

I returned last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo, where, in addition to the customary institutional meetings, I wanted to meet the representatives of the NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I must say they work very well. I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a weapon of war, where armed groups continue to
Committing repeated mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civilians, especially against women, the elderly and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of the Congo because it was a recent, as I said, very recent experience of mine.
But the appeal I want to make is aimed in general at the need for a strong and continuous condemnation against the brutal violations of women’s rights.
The international community must significantly increase the funds allocated to initiatives for the protection of women and other forms of violence.
violence, such as female genital mutilation, which is a serious violation of the human rights and physical integrity of women.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, represent a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious consequences not only for the health of those who suffer from it,
However, the costs to be sustained for direct and informal care are high.
The Alzheimer's disease, in fact, does not only affect the people who are struck by it, but also involves all those who take care of the patients.

It is therefore necessary to have a European response to the problem, a global coordination among the Member States, a synergy of concerted actions that mainly concern the scientific and research field and that take charge of the problem.

The strengthening of prevention, diagnosis, and the improvement of available treatments, even innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among States, are results achieved within the same framework, increasing citizens’ knowledge of the disease.

Thank you, President. The situation is that Campania, and in particular the city of Naples, have been universally known for some time, unfortunately, to the whole world, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue several times.

In the face of this now paradoxical situation, a third world one, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the point of view of Community law and what economic sanctions will be imposed on Italy in the event that the waste crisis in Campania does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I also ask if the Commission can provide in detail the data relating to the European funds that have been managed so far by the Campania Region for the creation of an integrated system of waste collection and disposal.
You see, Mr. Commissioner, usually when we talk about an emergency, we are talking about dramatic, extreme situations that, however, find a solution in a reasonable time.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, it is clear that something is not working.

The Italian government in these years has tried to do the best it could to solve the long-standing issue of the waste collection and disposal cycle. But evidently, if today the streets of Naples are full of barrels
The blame for the tons of rubbish is mainly to be attributed to the local Campanian authorities and their total inability or unwillingness to take action to find a solution.

It is clear, and absolutely beyond any doubt, that the conditions in which Naples and the Campania region find themselves are due to the negligence that has characterized, for many years, the management of the waste cycle by municipalities, provinces and regions.
If the separate collection is not carried out, which is the first and indispensable element of a waste management plan that works, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send the army, which happened a few weeks ago but also on other occasions, to replace hundreds of prison guards who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it is obviously not the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going quite differently, for example in my region, Veneto, where the differentiated collection has been done for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities of the emergency fall on the shoulders of the

on the Campanian politics and on the local administrators, and above all on the heavy collusion with the criminal underworld, which has always sought and obtained huge profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra in politics and in the local administrations.
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which in 2008 said to the Italians that the waste problem had been overcome, it is good that the European Union
to block funds to Italy until an eco-compatible waste cycle is presented, based on waste recycling and composting.

And it is not certain the plan that President Caldoro has presented, which is based once again on uncontrolled discharges, such as those in Chiaiano, Taverna del Re, Terzigno, even in the Vesuvius National Park, nor on incinerators that cause deaths and tumors, a real health emergency.
Public funds in Campania, in the environmental emergency of these 13 years, have consolidated criminal relations between politics, both left and right, entrepreneurs and the Camorra.

Environmental issues are resolved by criminalizing dissent, by criminalizing local communities, families and the territory, as the Italian government has done by using the baton to repress those who defend nature and the territory.

According to international law, a political refugee is a person who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality.
Cesare Battisti is not a political refugee.

Despite the cover offered for years by France, we are talking about a multiple murderer, the perpetrator and mastermind of four murders, who hid behind the pretext of political struggle to escape the gallows.
It is shameful for a great country like Brazil to deny the extradition of an unrepentant criminal, granting him political refugee status.
The Italian authorities, and especially the families of the victims, want to see this criminal brought to justice.
Faced with the arrogance of President Lula in the legal extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy receives the delivery of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening the suspension of cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
to give concrete support to the Tunisian people and their transitional government, to relaunch a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been strongly neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the young and the poor of the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the inequitable distribution of wealth and the limitations on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

North Africa is on fire and is asking for more democracy, more economy, more participation, more work and is looking with amazement at the old European continent, immobile, unable to grasp the social transformations that have occurred in that area and to develop real policies of progress and peace.
Europe should pay more attention to human rights and democracy, promote more dialogue, more collaboration, more real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.

The resolution approved today by a majority on the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.

No to the expansion of funds that simply consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs and the Camorra. Yes to European money if a credible plan is presented,
An environmentally friendly waste management plan, no to uncontrolled landfills in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, yes instead to recycling and environmentally friendly forms.
And it is also said no to the criminalization of the dissent of local communities, therefore yes to legality.

All the players, the moments and the dismissals of the pharmaceutical chain. Safety, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain, achieving a good compromise.

of counterfeit medicines, leading to a more positive and complete regulatory framework, capable of safeguarding the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.
From the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding a more equitable distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and armed cars, we must move on to true democracy, a new constitution, new elections, the abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights and freedom.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean, with this measure, are entering a phase that is even more urgent than the actions we have taken.
I believe that the act we are enacting today is much more important than the effects of the 2006 Community Regulation.

I think this also responds to some limits of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has often left large sectors of the fishing industry to support the idea that yes, Europe does its part, but the other countries of the river do not.
I think it is strategic for us to address the issue in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work done by colleague Rivellini, which was widely shared, I believe deserves a formal thank you in this setting.
Nevertheless, I have the clear feeling that the fact that we are not able to solve this issue in the first reading and we will get to the second reading.
In particular, it raises a question about the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation. On this occasion, Parliament sides with the Commission.

The Parliament essentially says that it is good that these delegated acts are in the hands of the Commission and there is some resistance from the Council. Moreover, today's absence is also a significant absence.
But this act makes the idea mature in Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea, is also this operation the future of fishermen.
But having said that, I think that the phase we are facing must bring back the idea of co-decision in a central way.
These delegated acts have a reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today to the Commission, but international agreements must maintain their role in Parliament when these occur.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion, we have two problems, one of method and the other of substance in this matter.

The method is that we are behaving through a device, for which we thank the Honourable Fraga, which is that of the oral interrogation to talk about something that should instead be, after the Treaty of Lisbon, a right of this Parliament.
I think that this practice should end. We cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a co-decision process.
Co-decision is such when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are having this debate, the treaty will be completed, it will go ahead and we will say yes or no at the end.
Well, this method must be converted.

As for the merits, I just wanted to point out, in agreement with many of my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of the fishing agreements, so that these are not just mere commercial agreements through which we go to buy cephalopods at one euro per kilo in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability and, above all, the impact on the economy of that country, understand how many jobs are modified, understand what the rate of innovation is for artisanal fishing, understand the use of these resources.
It is not just a simple commercial exchange, but a fishing agreement with all its implications.
President, the favorable vote expressed in relation to the honorable Rivas is the result of an evaluation of the management of the H1N1 influenza.
N1, which was in 2009-2010, which aims to prepare general guidelines for conduct, valid in any future occasions of global health emergencies.
The relationship, following a long and positive phase of re-elaboration, makes cooperation, independence and transparency its main pillars.
It aims for greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, in order to be able to provide a harmonized and coordinated risk management.
The objectives are the review of the strategy of the Member States as regards the national pandemic influenza preparedness plan, including vaccine stockpiles, the publication of names,
a team of experts consulted by the European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media in charge of disseminating public health messages.
This is why it received our vote of approval.

Thank you, Mr. President. Until today, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been received by the Community legislation on a provisional basis, through annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern conservation, management, exploitation, control and marketing measures for fishing and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
However, the permanent nature of such recommendations requires a more stable legal instrument for their reception in Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to receive the recommendations in question through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations can be added.
Today we have done this and this will improve legal certainty while at the same time taking an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the parties to the CGMP are obliged to ensure full implementation of the agreed measures as of the date established.
The temporary transposition was therefore necessary in order to make such international measures directly applicable to natural and legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty.

Mr. President, I believe that the approval of the report by colleague Podima represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, advanced and strong economic and fiscal policy in the European field.

It is now evident to everyone the urgency of equipping ourselves as Europe, as a coordination among the 27 countries, with economic and financial tools capable of governing the economy and not just suffering it.
For this reason, the proposal for a tax on financial transactions has had a great echo, a great discussion, a great attention.
The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this rule is an important and significant fact, because for the first time it did not let it go and instead it took a step forward.
I hope that the Commission and the Council will continue on this path.

...favourably the relations on equality between men and women and on female poverty in Europe. I am pleased that this has been discussed today, on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002/73 on equal treatment between men and women as regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and working conditions, further efforts are still needed to achieve proper compliance.

Just think that, despite the fact that the level of female education has increased a lot in recent years and the number of female graduates is now higher than that of male graduates, women are still concentrated in traditionally female sectors, often less paid, and occupy fewer positions of responsibility in all spheres of society.
The lack of access to care services for dependent people, such as children, disabled and elderly people, to adequate leave arrangements and flexible work formulas prevent women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women who are fighting for the most basic rights in the world and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations who are taking to the streets today, inviting women to demonstrate without the hijab.
Like all the colleagues who have spoken, I say that finally we are talking again and I hope that we will soon act again, also with specific choices in economic policy, in common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by the colleague and the communication by President Tajani.

This choice means some important things. First, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the maintenance of employment also, and perhaps above all, depend on the recovery and support of all sectors.
to the manufacturing sector, to the most advanced sectors and also to the traditional ones, because there is a frontier that can still be faced, and this was not so obvious until some time ago.

Secondly, the recovery of the industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not played out in the financial and tertiary sectors, but even here, and it is not too late to do so, we can set a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness with the rest of the world in the industrial sectors.

The third point is that it has been said that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, it focuses on factors and tools that can really promote new businesses, new capacity for maintenance and updating.

I believe it is important to highlight, as has been done, these new factors that need to be addressed: credit. We are calling for new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner on the issue of credit, raw materials, energy costs,

Innovation, research, the need to enhance in Europe the capacity to transfer technology, the results of research and innovation within companies, in new products and in new ways and organization of production.

We have to enhance a very peculiar fabric in our Europe, in some countries in particular, that of SMEs, that of the quality of companies, of the quality of products, in short, of the peculiarity of industry in Europe.
And I believe that we should rediscover, let's say, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries to innovate and change them.
Finally, the issue of the territory, which is very important.
European policies are successful if they are cross-cutting and if the territory is able to deal with them.
So, thank you to Lange and we hope for excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a short time.
Many milestones have been reached, but some battles still need to be fought.
Today the urgency concerns women from other cultures who live in Europe and in the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festival without putting the issue of women in the Arab-Muslim world at the center. Otherwise, we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but will soon become ours as well.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that are growing year after year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
For some time now, there has been an increase in cases of violence of all kinds suffered by Muslim women within their own families.

For this reason, I have been asking for some time, and I am asking again today, that Europe implements policies aimed at combating the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor crimes, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We European women and men must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic integralism.

Thank you, President. I voted in favor of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform that took place on September 12th was unanimously recognized as an important step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken and I express concern in this regard for the numerous arrests of journalists.

I would like to point out that Turkey is the seventh commercial partner of the European Union, that the European Union is the main commercial partner of Turkey and that trade, correctly interpreted for centuries, has favored the interpenetration and peaceful knowledge of peoples.

I therefore applaud the significant progress made in promoting and connecting the European Union and Turkey, particularly through the motorways of the sea that cross the northern Adriatic and the northern Tyrrhenian Sea.

on which a flow of over 250,000 trucks per year now moves in both directions, in connection with an important railway link, which is a truck-to-wagon transfer from the port to internal European destinations.

President, with today's vote we have given further impetus to the definitive solution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to recall that the over 300 amendments presented in the report were transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all adopted, which aim to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, as well as the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, will have to ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and best practices, and the Member States should appoint a high-level government official who will act as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more incisive and less hypocritical if in the report we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should respect in the host countries.
This is my wish, that is, that solutions are found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all Member States.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans, which the island can barely accommodate.
For weeks, Italy has been the target of hundreds of boats carrying illegal immigrants.
And if we do not react together, if the EU does not react, the migratory wave of people fleeing will continue.
The illegal immigrants who have arrived in the last few months must be sent home. There is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond some words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions. Where is Europe?
Up to now, Brussels has been completely absent, it has had a shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer stand.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

Instead, Europe must not only help Italy in the repatriation of illegal immigrants, but it must also support the efforts of the Italian government to prevent thousands and thousands of people from continuing to leave, especially from Tunisia.

The same cannot be said for the Libyan refugees, on which Europe must stand by Italy in the identification and logistical management operations, but above all it must commit itself so that the refugees are hosted in all member states.
The reception of those fleeing from war cannot only be the responsibility of Italy.
It’s time to stop talking.
If the European Union exists, it should make itself heard.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants while France pushes them back with shameful methods.
The clandestine must be sent back home, while all the Member States must commit themselves to welcoming the Libyan refugees.
Yes, Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the issue of providing adequate financial resources to ensure the decommissioning of nuclear plants is a problem that has already been addressed by the...
The European Union's legislation on nuclear safety is currently very topical, in light of recent international events and the consequent decisions of the Union's governments on the matter.

The work of the Honourable Marinescu, which we have expressed our support for, addresses the specific cases of some countries that, at the time of their accession, have assumed particular obligations in terms of the decommissioning of nuclear plants and that have received special support from the European Union for this activity.
Beyond the specific cases, it is necessary to establish an effective control and verification system, as well as an examination of the nuclear power plants present in the territory of the Union.
The number of reactors that are expected to be decommissioned in the near future in the Community area is indeed high.

It will therefore be essential to ensure the guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the allocation of adequate financial resources necessary to deal with both ordinary and extraordinary needs.

We support the idea of an internal market capable of understanding and satisfying social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
It is not a utopia, it is realism and also modernity.

It is indeed this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because the only economic element, economicism in essence, the reduction of the market to economicism, has shown how all this does not solve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
It is, in short, a matter of fully realizing, here and now, the idea of a European social market economy.
In today’s tests, this is present.
There is the recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, 10% of European companies and a large part of our employment.
They are realities that are real companies, a demonstration of economic pluralism and business pluralism.
They work with capital but not for capital and want to achieve work, welfare, quality and social innovation and demonstrate that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

The justification given by Beijing that the artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic crimes is not convincing, nor is it convincing that such harsh treatment was meted out to a free and dissident artist.
It is not convincing, since such an arrest is part of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression of any dissent.

China has opened up to the West on an economic level, but without combining production with respect for the environment and workplace safety, and it is unable to open up to democracy and pluralism.
