Thank you, President. Thanks to the Amsterdam Treaty, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater importance and the
Attention has focused on the integration of economic policy with environmental policy and on the inclusion of environmental issues in policies in other sectors.

The key sectors include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, invited the Union and its Member States to extend the national accounts to the fundamental aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favor of this regulation proposal because it creates new uses for national accounting data and for environmental statistics and for other statistical sectors.
Thank you, President. My vote in favor of the Garriga report on the Union's near financial prospects stems from the conviction that precisely in one of the moments of greatest crisis,
that the so-called European spirit is decisive in insisting and winning on the indispensability of providing credible tools, starting with an adequate financial endowment, to the Union.

Therefore, the request for an additional 5% for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable to provide answers to the major issues before us. Indeed, these resources are needed to
addressing real problems such as greater cohesion between regions, greater research and innovation capacity, and greater capacity to generate growth and provide employment. Indeed, without resources

None of these problems will find a sufficient answer without adequate measures. Starting from the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not cause damage to the other existing categories.
This is why I voted in favor and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the indications of this report.

Thank you, President. The new Hungarian Constitution reduces the possibility of intervention by control bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the Executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of powers.
Social rights are emptied out, the State provides subsidies to the needy only if they accept to carry out public utility work.
Finally, the right to self-defense is sanctioned, which allows the possession of weapons at home even without a license.
The right to abortion is denied and rules that are highly discriminatory towards homosexuals are introduced.
All this is contrary to Directive No. 78/2000, which establishes a general framework for the fight against discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are scarcely compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

Honourable colleagues, we are about to vote on a strategic document of great relevance, which offers a solid framework of reference for the negotiations on the financial prospects for the post-2013 period.

Starting from the request for consistency between objectives and tools, between the new role that European institutions are called to play after Lisbon and in the face of the recession, and the resources that we decide to invest together.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation that emerges from public opinion, from the recipients of EU policies, from European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter to decide what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
It tells us that cohesion is today a vital node of the European project, an important heritage for all, to be safeguarded, protected and innovated.

Particularly critical on this front is the effort made on the hypothesis of introducing an intermediate category of regions, especially because in several cases the years of recession we have behind us have

It has exacerbated internal divisions, making it even more important to provide efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe, fighting waste and making the development policy more transparent.
However, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is a challenge that we must accept to open a new phase in politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to give substance to the cohesion policy, that more balanced and sustainable development that we want to guarantee to Europe in the next years.
I also join in thanking the Honourable Langen and the other colleagues with whom we worked to put together this complex report.
I believe that what the Honourable
Langen was happy when he said that we want to maintain the scope, the field of application of this regulation, in line with what was the mandate of the G20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental objective is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms in order to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of risk.

Risk and speculation. When you get to the point, as has happened, of exchanging, of insuring 400 million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, you understand what risks we are running.

Having said that, however, I would also like to mention two problems. The first problem is the relationship with the Council. The second problem is the coherence of the proposal for reform of the financial markets that we must pursue.

I raise the first problem regarding the Council, and I say it very clearly: the feeling is that too often the Council represents an obstacle to doing things quickly and well in terms of financial market reform.
I hope that the new Presidency will take charge of this problem, because even on this occasion we must put the
I note a lengthening of the times which is largely due to the positions, difficulties and contrasts that emerge in the Council.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second issue is the organic nature and specificity of the measures.
There is not only the measure on OTCs, there is also the measure on short selling and on other things.

I would like to recall two points: the specific issue of the commodities market, a particular market that requires specific anti-speculative interventions, and the problem of the exposure to derivatives of local authorities in the countries of the European Union.
I think that these are problems that Parliament should intervene in.
Thank you, President. The Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences with the loss of radioactive water into the sea, 6,500 times higher than the legal limits.
The risk of food contamination is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this only applies to fresh products.
No regulations have been issued to protect processed products, particularly canned fish.
We import 370,000 tons of canned tuna, the main suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that the canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is fundamental and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the place where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently recognized this and plans to fill this gap with the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, which however will not come into force before two years, just as the Sommer report, under discussion in this plenary, will not be effective before three years.
We must not create alarmism, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope. The hope is that the Polish presidency will contribute to the battle against the Europe of national egotisms.
national, without looking to the future, that it is a contribution in favour of a Europe that truly thinks of itself as an integrated reality with a common destiny.
But as you rightly said in your speech, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and solve.
In this short time, I would like to point out two crucial issues on the economic and financial crisis front.
First question: the reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem, it is a major democratic issue of our time. The times are too long. We need to close issues such as the one related to the reform of short selling and OTCs.

Second point. We have the issue of the taxation of financial transactions in front of us. We need to get to the heart of the matter. We expect a concrete contribution from the Polish Presidency in this regard.
More than 20 years have passed since the signing of the Schengen Agreements.
No one questions the advantages of free movement, but it must be recognized that the current setup is no longer adequate for current and future needs.

For this reason, all Member States must commit to reviewing the Schengen operating mechanisms so that freedom of movement does not come at the expense of the legitimate security needs of our citizens.

As far as we know, the Commission's guidelines can also be partly shared, especially as regards the introduction of a mechanism that allows States to temporarily reinstate border controls in case of emergency.
However, we need to see how this will happen and whether the statements will be followed by actions and, above all, concrete results.

Certainly, it will also be necessary to implement a general reform of the European border protection system, especially the external ones, on which it is necessary for Frontex to become, as soon as possible, an agency with real powers of intervention and support for national authorities.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if we do not want to just survive.

The crisis has deeply affected the real lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, to irreversibly lower the social and cultural quality, the well-being and the future of young people and Europeans.

Other than values of cohesion and prosperity. Getting out of the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes. Remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must be cut to the quick, giving severe rules to financial markets.

Against recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that places the person one step below profit, remedies against a resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are due to it today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, even new ones, to move forward, to start the engines of growth, with research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure and work, because without work people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervenche Berès and her colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a proud Europe, aware of its role.
To the European leaderships, if they exist, now it is their responsibility to act.

The speaker has the floor. One minute. Thank you, President. Behind the widespread prosperity of our continent there is a hidden Europe, often invisible, of which we speak as numbers, statistics, sociology, and not as people with a body and soul, often women and children or elderly people, that is, the most fragile population.
But Europe will not be credible to its citizens if it does not learn to be coherent. And we here want to be coherent in this Parliament and in this phase of Europe’s life.

And so, if we say that we are founding the Union on values, on human rights, I do not think that we can interrupt or cut so drastically a program for those who do not eat, in short, for those who do not have the right to food, access to food, the right to food.

fundamental. For a legal issue that is resolved, is it an agricultural fund, is it a social fund? And if it is social, Madam Commissioner, it should not be at the expense of other social programs, but rather a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
Let's say we want to guarantee food security to Europeans, but the first right to security is to have food, which is then healthy.
So, here is our consistency and our commitment.
Let us therefore find a legal solution that ensures continuity and, with the help of non-governmental organizations and volunteers, guarantees the first fundamental human right, that of food.
Mr. President, just to support this report and to highlight two aspects in particular. One because it fits into the debate currently underway on the
The revision of the Common Fisheries Policy and the fundamental option, which is linked to the regionalization of a policy that in recent years, being centralized, has shown all its weaknesses.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained in the report by colleague Jotova describe a particular situation, but one that can be repeated in the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea is not different.

In the Tyrrhenian Sea or in the Ionian Sea, that is, the interactions especially between European fishing and extra-European fishing, so to speak, are often very harmful to European markets and to European consumers.
The second issue I would like to quickly highlight is that of the reference to a common coast guard.
There is no politics without the exercise of control.

Today, controls are carried out by disparate forces in Europe. I believe that the time has come to understand how one of the first European law enforcement forces, namely the coast guards, can have a common management, a greater correlation and, why not, a single European body.
With this auspice, I fully support the contents of the report by my colleague Iotova.

Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that hit the Gulf of Mexico more than a year ago has prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation related to the activity of offshore oil platforms.
The European Parliament, with this report, also wanted to express its position on the matter, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capacities
It is addressed to the operators in the sector and aims to establish high safety standards, thus consolidating the EU's role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new interventions in the matter requested by the Commission will have to focus on international coordination and on a realistic approach that combines all the existing excellences.
at the level of procedures and without creating new bodies or additional bureaucracy that would risk moving away from the achievement of concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to the greater accountability of the operating companies, requires the improvement of communication mechanisms and the sharing of information and knowledge, and aims at the strengthening and expansion of the role and skills of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved, thanks to the negotiation on this text, to which we have expressed our support, to be positive.
I thank colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, I also thank Commissioner Edegaard.

I believe that we are here today discussing and reasoning to try to really achieve a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been recalled so far, have mainly focused on reducing CO2 emissions. It is important, however, that this...
The proposal highlights how we must also tackle the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting on climate change.

Many things have already been mentioned, which I believe it is right to keep in mind. Today we are able to do it at absolutely reasonable costs, we have the technologies available and, although it is in doubt that CO2 emissions are mainly responsible,

And while it is undeniable that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are in much smaller quantities, it is also undeniable that their potential is very high, and that therefore we will really be able to achieve significant results in a few years, in a few decades.
important

There are signals, it has been recalled, also in the United States by the Commissioner, I saw a study that was published on Nature, precisely by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce, which I find...

There are many points of contact with the analysis carried out by our colleagues, and I imagine that these too will be among the things that will allow Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more concrete and important position.

I would just like to remind you, as has already been mentioned, that in this extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are experiencing, we were talking about the homeless just a few minutes ago, there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account and therefore, considering that the great...

Sensitivity, obviously, first and foremost for jobs, we should be able to also run a communication campaign that explains to citizens what we concretely want to do in the direction of development and their well-being and the protection of jobs. Thank you.
The single market, free circulation, the Treaty of Lisbon are all elements that have come into play regardless of a change in our way of legislating, the European way and the national way.

It is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions, in particular it is necessary to really start a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and the individual states.

I would start from our documents. I take this opportunity to suggest a sort of clarity test on our documents. When we make a white book, a green book, everything must be more understandable. And I come to say that the real and perhaps strategic proposal for our Europe and to really start

This virtuous phase of the start of legislation should be the one to assign a specific delegation to a European Commissioner who specifically deals with clarifying the legislation and the relations between the States and the European Union.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Council representative and Madam Commissioner, first of all, I would like to positively welcome, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved on June 6.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and to combat it, European-scale measures are needed.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe should do more.
How can we blame them?

In many Member States, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption. Just think that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, on citizens' rights and on trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures to counter it, adopted so far by the Member States, are insufficient to contain a phenomenon in expansion.

It is the European Union that must give a united and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis that is weighing on people's lives, on the sustainability of pension and welfare systems, and on the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes a loss of 120 billion euros every year, equivalent to 1% of the EU’s GDP, and daily diverts resources from the Union and its Member States.
They could be used to provide basic services, such as education, childcare, employment, transport, in short, to divert clean resources to the support of people.

It is therefore necessary to have more courage and firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by intensifying and strengthening measures to combat corruption at the Union level.

In particular, we cannot talk about fighting corruption if we are not able to adopt, at the very least, minimum standards for the definition of the crime of corruption, which is not even mentioned in the recently approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters to measure the extent of the phenomenon in the Member States, which is essential to provide an effective response.
We are in favor, for example, of relaunching the network of the EU's contact points against corruption, as proposed by the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
ISI is not new, it has been around for several years.
It is perhaps time to make a critical assessment of the policies followed so far. Has everything always been done well?
We have always made appropriate analyses of the situation.
Was the right approach chosen?
The same European Central Bank, which, as Minister Rostowski says, has saved Europe, has always done well, even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem, the speed of the markets and the slowness of politics. But is this the only problem?

Of course, if we think that we are still implementing the 21st of July, this should at least suggest preparing and organizing the summits and their conclusions better. But politics will always be slower than markets.
So the point is to look further ahead, to shift the focus to the fight against unemployment and development.

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on the indications of growth and development.

The Commission should go beyond its weakness, state that the priority is the fight against unemployment and job creation, redistribution of wealth and a strategy of public investments, changing also the rules of the new European Stability Pact.
Mr. President, I believe that the challenge of the next few years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its primacy as the first...
a world tourist destination and at the same time be able to enhance, both in terms of environmental protection and competitive capacity, all its territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and not taken for granted task, also in light not only of the opportunities but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani reminded us, it becomes crucial, as also highlighted in the opinion of the Commission that we approved in the Regional Development Commission,
To combine a strong general strategy of the whole European Union on tourism with a valorization of the role of regions and territories.
In this sense, it is essential to have full involvement from the beginning, respecting the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Moreover, I believe that the development of networks and integrated tourism projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
It also seems fair to me to propose identifying a European brand that is able to define a high quality of the tourist product.
Obviously, the Commission will have to define the priorities better, especially from a financial point of view, to ensure that Europe's primacy is maintained in the future.

President, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the financing of research and innovation is one of the greatest opportunities that development and the European economy have before them.

It is indeed a matter of acting on the lever that can really trigger a moment of growth and also of new qualified employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to the new opportunities of innovation, technology and related professions.
An observation that emerges from this work is that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that lead to practical applications, that lead to
To give birth to new companies, which arrive at new patents and which do not remain pure basic research, pure knowledge, important yes, but not such as to really trigger the development ball.

The second observation is the relationship with local bodies, the regions and the territories, which are an important tool for territorial planning and for the meeting between research, universities, centres of excellence and businesses.

Thank you, President. The European schools were created with the aim of guaranteeing access to education in their mother tongue to the children of the agents of the European institutions who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of the country of origin.
The first European school was created in Luxembourg in 1953, on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, given the positive nature of this form of teaching, 14 European schools have been created within the various Member States.

While recognizing how the system of European schools represents a necessity more than a luxury, it is evident that more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, such a system can present obsolete aspects and must in some way be adapted and adapted to the new economic and social needs.

I therefore voted in favor of the text of my colleague Cavada, which calls for greater involvement of the European Union to support and coordinate the actions of the Member States, which are called upon to work to develop and improve the system of European schools.
And investing, we know that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans. Thank you, President. Thank you, Honourable Zanicchi. The floor is now open to Honourable...
Thank you, Mr. President. In the last few decades, the exponential increase in the number of natural disasters has caused the death of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Development Commission, I followed the work of the report on the European Union's ability to react to disasters, in which
it emerged how much still needed to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the increasing number of earthquakes, landslides and tsunamis.
The European Union's response to the earthquake in Haiti, for example, clearly showed the complexity of the existing instruments and procedures.

Even if the Member States and the Community institutions have acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis has raised a number of problems in terms of efficiency, coordination and transparency.
For this very reason, I have expressed a favorable vote for the text of colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which aims for greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management, greater coordination
between the parties involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlaps and time losses that may hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
Yes, it is just a good initiative. I believe that it will be a matter of building a European policy in the field of tourism.
The European brand is a good intuition, but I would like to dwell on two issues. There is no sea or coastal tourism without a policy of coastal planning.

I believe that Europe should now take the initiative to protect this important sector, so that the concept of the sea and the concept of the coasts is not limited to a sort of urban planning that ends at the water's edge and does not comprehensively involve the sea.
I believe that an integrated policy in this sense is useful, just as it will be necessary to build everything that lies behind the statements of rural tourism. Rural tourism can be...
A good source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where there is no more work, where it is important instead that depopulation does not continue and that there is human settlement.

Well, there it is not enough to just make statements, but we should suggest to Europe and to individual states to intervene on the fiscal lever. Doing tourism in rural areas means maybe paying less taxes. Perhaps this way we really build a true opportunity for the tourism resource and for those who live there.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to express my congratulations for the work done by the Honourable Fidanza, which logically fits into the framework of the actions
initiatives and promoted at the community level in the field of tourism, after the Treaty of Lisbon assigned new skills to the EU in the sector.
I share and want to underline the statement of the importance of a Europe as a unitary destination of certified and quality tourism and the will to promote this.
The same idea, translated into action at the level of structures, allocation of resources, funding, coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the Union countries.

An approach to be valued and rewarded, given the sector in question with its developments in terms of percentage of GDP, production, employment and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Companies, attention to the protection and enhancement of the environment, is able to develop and therefore to respond to the main challenges posed by the present day.
For all these reasons, I consider this relationship to be positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Thank you, President, also for the recovery. Three small considerations. We need more Europe, even here.
I believe it is inevitable that in some areas there is really an attitude in which not only is Europe hoped for, but it is also built.
More Europe means, for example, starting to think about a real common highway police, with identical rules in terms of protection and security.
More Europe means having a European policy on training, not simply delegating this to individual states, but building, for example, a real training policy.
As far as schools, young people and even more at-risk categories are concerned, motorcyclists were mentioned a moment ago, but we could also talk about truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within vehicles that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol and anti-drug tools.
I believe that it is a specific strategy to be built with the car companies and with the European production of cars.
Well, I believe that if all this falls within the conviction of a common policy, I really think that perhaps the conditions will improve.

Thank you, President. This report addresses a topic, that of global food security. Global means that this topic is not only about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the topic of food supply concerns all communities, even those of the most developed countries.

Between some lines, such as the essential one of the coherence between European policies and this objective of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but often is not coherent in its choices.
I only want to outline, however, the titles of three innovative lines that I believe we should develop further.
The first one, food supply is currently at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which should be contained if not prevented, derivatives, etc.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, because it puts democracy at risk, as well as the survival of many peoples.
Thirdly, the coherence between supply and energy policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the world’s peoples.
I voted in favor of this report by Mr. Zimmer, first of all for a reason of
It is purely political in nature, because I think it is necessary to bring back to the center of the initiative of the entire European Union this great issue of food security.

It is not just a matter of helping developing countries to tackle this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, since it is expected that from now until 2050 the demand for food will increase by over 70 per cent.

Agricultural products. It is a major issue that, if not addressed in a timely and decisive manner, will become one of the main threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace and even democracy, as we have seen.

For this reason, I believe it is essential that the entire European Union, together with the Member States, make all the necessary efforts, starting with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction to seriously address this major issue.
Greetings to the Commission. I must really thank all the people who have contributed in these weeks, in these months, to the production of this document that we are voting on in the Assembly today.
We worked, I must say, very well and a truly constructive debate developed.
The resolution proposal that we are voting on today is the result of a truly common effort and is the fruit of the contribution of all political forces and of the entire Parliament.
I believe that a strong common sensitivity has developed regarding this issue, also because, we must remember, we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we look at them in their raw form, are very eloquent. The number of disasters in the world has quintupled. If we think that in 1975
78 catastrophic events were recorded, while today we are facing almost 400 calamitous events per year.

In the last 20 years, unfortunately, the victims of these disasters have been 90,000 and more than 29 million people have been affected by disasters, while the economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is clear that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that require a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly strong commitment on our part.
We all have in our minds the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flooding in Pakistan, what happened in Japan.
Europe itself sees sudden floods and fires on its territory every year. We remember the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
There is no need to go further to affirm how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
the fundamental principles, which are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause of the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are moving along these lines.
The intervention of the European Union has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced by the work of our Commissioner Georgieva, but today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A quality leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to a response where the reaction
...is strengthened through the preventive identification of the means available in the Member States and made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is important to emphasize that for this quality leap and to move from information sharing and emergency response to planning, monitoring and control roles,

The coordination that we are calling for, the fundamental role of services such as GMS, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern there is for what is happening with the budget for these new technologies that are fundamental.
We have included the importance of communicating with citizens, because even this has been taught to us a lot by the Japanese experience, it is never enough, it is never sufficient.
We are waiting for the Commission, to which we ask to present as soon as possible the proposal regarding civil protection in legislative form.
Ethnic minorities oppressed, Christians forced to live their faith in hiding, priests brutally murdered without the authorities lifting a finger, anti-Western foreign policy: this is today’s Turkey.
My party, the Northern League, has always been against Turkey's entry into Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse of radical Islamism in our continent.
Today more than ever we are convinced that the EU must put an end to the negotiations for accession.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has made against Europe must have an immediate response.
It is not acceptable that a third country tells Europe what to do.
Cyprus is a full member of the EU and has the undisputed right to take on the rotating presidency.
Europe must give a clear signal and show itself ready to defend Cyprus with all means against the arrogance and political-military preponderance of Turkey.
Let us immediately interrupt the negotiations for accession and be ready to suspend commercial relations.
President, we are experiencing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European construction.
Having this awareness would mean getting out of a myopic logic that subordinates everything to an ideological will to balance the books.
We all want the accounts of the various States to be in order, we all want to reduce the debt.
However, it is clear that without an intelligent investment policy, capable of breathing new life into the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear result in this setting is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the weakest classes.
For this reason, together with the group of Socialists and Democrats, we voted against this report.
In fact, we are moving in a single direction, that of austerity without growth, a direction that has so far proved to be wrong.
I very much appreciated the work done by colleague Ferrera on this report.
In fact, on the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, we, my group and I, have expressed a positive vote only on this.

We did it because, among other things, a clause was inserted to protect social rights starting from collective bargaining and, moreover, there is a strengthening of the role of Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

Therefore, while it is not possible to change the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report certainly takes a step forward, among other things, to have a surveillance system that takes into account fundamental rights.

And so, in this context, while maintaining that a vision, in our opinion, based only on a policy of austerity does not produce positive results, this report certainly constitutes a positive note in the opposite direction.

Honourable colleagues, Finland and Holland have opposed the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are not able to guarantee effective border control today and are the subject of widespread corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
The Europol, in its 2010 report on organized crime, also thinks so, not just the populist movements.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria were to join the Schengen area at this time, law enforcement and security agencies predict that the Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become the crossroads for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have many reservations about the real ability of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls, against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they have opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means opening the door to transnational crime and opening a breach in the European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons put forward are many and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what the intentions of the Commission and the Council are regarding this delicate issue, which in my opinion has so far been dealt with in a superficial manner.
without taking into account the risks that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in the field of security and international crime.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and give the go-ahead only when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have a negative impact on the security of European citizens.

Thank you, President. The crisis in Europe is intertwining in a vicious circle the problems of public budgets and private capital with those of the productivity of our companies. And the specter of recession is there.
If, therefore, the priority of the PMI is crucial, I ask the Commission that it must absolutely, together with the Parliament, ensure that our good principles are implemented.
and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete actions in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

If all Member States were to anticipate the application of the directive on late payments, what would happen, Mr. Commissioner? What a great advantage it would be for SMEs! So, SME tests are important, but we are still at the methodological level.

Of course, it is right to check if, when we legislate, we really do so in the interest and to the measure of small and medium-sized enterprises. But we ask that this be done with great constancy and tenacity, let's say, in depth, in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what is being done by the Commission, we are ready with the budget and with the other possibilities that we have to support it.
I will only say a word about credit.
Let's have a clear talk with the banks, I'm telling you, Commissioner, because we need to help small and medium-sized businesses.

In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through joint activity with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' trust in the internal market, can contribute to stimulating the European economy.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the report on the provisions for the sectors placed on the market and the flexibility regime, to which we have expressed our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has been

It has been concretized, on the one hand, by avoiding the establishment of requirements that are implausible and impossible to meet, and on the other hand, by providing a so-called flexibility regime that, by providing for time phases and corresponding quantitative limits,

It provides for the annual release on the market of a predetermined quota of tractors that meet certain characteristics and in this way allows the adjustment to the set standards to be spread over time without any trauma for the productive and industrial sectors involved.

Honourable Tartarella, the work done has been important and has managed to balance the needs dictated by the great challenges that the European Union is called upon to face in this period and those of environmental protection and the current economic crisis.
Thank you, President. The current global economic crisis, which is even more serious than that of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
The commercial disparities between countries, the financial markets lacking common rules, the instability of the banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, which I support, highlights the urgency of a new set of rules and a global economic governance.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, a more responsible monetary policy and more stringent supervision policies, and decision-making bodies and international economic organizations must be the main players at the center of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs a clear and stable framework to reduce the exasperated instabilities, also caused by globalization, and to guarantee reforms with a broad scope, aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment that this resolution underlines to all countries.

Thank you, President. I have expressed a favourable vote for the report by Honourable Colleague Matera, which analyses the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as already mentioned, more than 5% of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has the moral obligation to protect them and the text approved today supports those policies that can represent concrete help for these women, such as, for example, tax breaks for...
health assistance, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access to affordable housing and special unemployment benefits.
Only by adopting these measures can we respond to the needs of a category that is increasingly significant in all advanced and industrialized countries.

It is essential to focus on investments and not just on prudent budget management.

We can no longer allow ourselves to follow individual interests, but we must finally represent a single, compact subject ready for confrontation.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the challenges posed by modernity and the report of our colleague Senator Fidili, to which we have expressed our favorable vote, require us to put the citizen in his role as a consumer at the center.

at the heart of the community debate, and remind us that the protection of its interests cannot remain just a principle enshrined in the Treaty, but must be a concrete guiding principle of the policies of the European Union.

Waiting for the times. The policies to counter new and old poverty, unfortunately growing in today's Europe, in the Europe of the crisis of the last years and also of policies of austerity in a single direction, especially on the part of the States.

Financial commitments, new resources, both in the European budget, within the framework of the financial perspectives, and in European policies, as just mentioned, from the Social Fund to the Cohesion Fund, and in the budgets of individual States.
And above all, we should use the European semester to monitor, year after year, the policies that individual states dedicate to this fundamental challenge.

In order to make the goal of reducing poverty and social exclusion for around 20 million European citizens credible, it is therefore necessary to have consistency between the huge resources that Europe must make available, the States must make available, and the concrete policies that we can implement.
It is estimated that around 2 billion euros are needed from now until 2020 to achieve the goals we have set.

This is the challenge that we are pointing out and putting at the center of our attention as the Budget Commission: coherence between the financial resources that we make available and the policies that we implement.
...in difficulty in our countries, the elderly, women, young people, the disabled and millions of people and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation.
In the face of this situation, we are here to discuss plans to support the Roma community, housing to give to immigrants.
We must think about helping the categories that are really in difficulty and give financial and political support to the family, which is the institution on which our society is based.
We must help small and medium-sized businesses that are struggling with the crisis, because these SMEs are the real antidote to poverty and the real source of wealth in our countries.

Europe must direct its efforts and funds to these excluded people, now more than ever.

Thank you, Mr. President. I have expressed my favorable vote on the text on the work of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which, thanks to the quality of the work done, has established itself as a key player in cooperation between the North and the South of the world.
I myself, as a member of that Assembly, took part in the meetings held in Brussels and in the works held in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa in Congo in December of the same year.

Thanks to these visits, I was able to see first-hand, as I had already done in 2009 in Angola, the sad conditions experienced daily by certain peoples and at the same time evaluate the efforts made by the ACP to improve things.

In conclusion, I feel I should emphasize that, in a particular historical and political moment, especially for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, the role played by the ICC has been crucial.

It is of fundamental importance, especially in the context of the supervision of negotiations for economic partnership agreements, to promote the transparency of such processes and the development of disadvantaged local realities.
Thank you, Honourable Zanichelli. Thank you, President. Personally, I find the creation of a European Heritage brand interesting.

At a time when, due to the persistent economic crisis, a certain Euroscepticism is spreading in many Member States, do you believe that an initiative of this kind can strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union?

The distinctive element of the European brand is not the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value that it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens on the path towards better intercultural dialogue.
Thank you, Mr. President. In December 2009, I took part in the COP15 in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament delegation.

About two years have passed and I regret to say that the work done and the commitments made in Copenhagen, then formalized in Cancun, will not be enough to achieve the goal of limiting the annual average temperature increase on our planet to 2 degrees Celsius.

Some major emitting countries, such as Japan or Russia, seem to want to distance themselves from the commitments they have made. Others do not seem to give the problem of climate change the right priority.

Today, while expressing my favorable vote, I am aware that only with the great and firm will of the Heads of State and Governments in the world will we be able to create the premises for a complete international agreement.
The potential of the Internet for both the economy and a more participatory and inclusive society is still huge.
Today, in the phase of transposition of the Telecom package into national legislation, there is a risk of fragmentation of the European framework.
The monitoring role of the Commission will therefore be important, and I also say the role of BEREC, which some of us would have liked to be stronger, even in the definition of the telecom package.

The priorities that we want to reiterate in this debate are: network neutrality guarantee, broadband infrastructure development and development of more open software, access security and interoperability of systems, promotion of the use of

Digital technologies in the various industrial and service sectors, production of digital content and new services, inclusion of those currently excluded (I am thinking of the disabled, but not only), defence of informational and cultural pluralism.

It will also be provided and guaranteed that operators cannot make blocks, put blocks, limitations or discriminations to the detriment of users and that their transparency in commercial offers and in all their activities is maximum.

Thank you, Mr. President. We all know how important the role played by the International Criminal Court is, which is responsible for prosecuting the perpetrators of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times the Court has been increasingly subject to unjust political attacks.
Its arrest warrants have often been ignored and this is why the current balance is not proportional to the efforts and commitment made.

I therefore expressed my favorable vote for the text approved today because it is the duty of the European Union to carry out all political, diplomatic and logistical actions to support the Court and guarantee its independence and correct and effective functioning.
Thank you, thank you President. The phosphates present in detergents for domestic washing machines end up in water systems, in rivers, streams and European lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various forms of life. As a result, algae and other fast-growing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae removes oxygen from other living organisms, and can also produce toxins, destroying fish and plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore voted in favor of the text voted on today because, in order to purify the European water heritage, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is poured into the waters of our continent.

Thank you, thank you President. The text presented by colleague Lisek analyses the possible measures to be implemented to reduce the costs of defence, which weigh heavily on the community budget in a period of financial crisis.
The main proposals concern better coordination of the planning of the defence system, the sharing and pooling of defence capabilities, support for research and technological development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur’s positions, according to which the economic and financial crisis that has hit us can constitute an opportunity for the integration of policies.
European Union defence policies, giving the impetus to draft and finally implement those ambitious reforms that for years have been in a stalemate.
For these reasons, I have expressed my favorable vote.
Thank you very much, Mr President. The Arab Spring and the events that followed have made it necessary to review the European Neighbourhood Policy.

It is clear that, at the current state of affairs, relations with the countries in question must be more focused on cooperation in order to ensure the priority of democracy and security on both shores of the Mediterranean.

In this regard, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is essential to strengthen mutual respect and tolerance with partner countries in the neighborhood, while at the same time promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I voted in favor, of course. Thank you.
Please, Honourable Domenici. Thank you, thank you Mr President. Yesterday in Florence an extremely serious event occurred which causes horror and dismay. A man...
A 50-year-old man opened fire in two markets in the city of Florence on five Senegalese citizens. Two of them died and three are now hospitalized in serious condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
This is a racist and xenophobic far-right person who wanted to kill people who are only guilty of having black skin.
Florence is my city and before being elected to the European Parliament I was mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, awarded the gold medal for its resistance to Nazifascism.

Yet, it was in Florence that this abominable racist crime took place, demonstrating that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest itself anywhere and one should never think of having eradicated it once and for all.

Mr. President, I ask you to express the condolences of the European Parliament and to reaffirm the commitment of this House against all forms of racism and for the respect and rights of every human being. Thank you.
Mr. President, the management of projects in war zones such as Afghanistan is not directly comparable to the management carried out in the
developed countries or countries not affected by conflicts, with aid evidently hampered also by the stable security situation.
However, it is necessary to try to understand the reasons for the shortcomings, the management of the projects and the related risk factors in order to improve the situation as much as possible.
I share the position of the rapporteur who invites the Commission to pay more attention to fraud, corruption, non-compliance and the effectiveness of specific projects.
It is therefore necessary to increase the transparency and accountability of the use of Union funds and to help both Member States and other donors to avoid common mistakes.
We don't have time to go into details or to discuss the issue in depth, but I think we must acknowledge that there are some points that remain very critical.
