The old approach, which no longer reflected the real global geopolitical situation, has been overcome.
We continue to work on a photograph of the world of the 90s, a photograph that is quite old. If we look at it in perspective, projected towards 2050, it is truly unsustainable.
We see that by 2050, among the top 30 economies in the world, there should be 19 countries that are currently still on the list of developing countries.
I believe that this change of pace is perhaps the most interesting fact from a political point of view and it has in fact been underlined by our colleague Florence in a precise manner.
I also think that we should no longer proceed in separate compartments.

And so, recalling also what Mario Draghi, the governor of the European Central Bank, said the other day right here in this institution, if we want to push in this sector towards what are the priorities, that is,

In order to achieve growth and employment, we must be concrete and focus mainly on the technologies of the green economy, to truly achieve sustainable development and to respond to the most important needs of our citizens.

Thank you. Europe is shrinking, stock markets are collapsing, the Europe of financial lobbies is falling apart, but the Danish President opens her semester promising total loyalty to the Commission’s plans for the creation of a super economic government of the continent.
Instead of focusing on measures to be taken to save the fate of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as a faithful watchdog of the Eurocracy in the Council.
Other passages, however, I do not agree with at all.
First of all, I do not see how it is possible to propose today as a priority the acceleration of the process of enlargement of the EU towards the Balkan countries.
There are other problems to be addressed immediately before worrying about how to integrate countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then Turkey. The Danish government is strongly pushing for Turkey's accession.
Fortunately, Turkey is still far from meeting the criteria set by the EU for membership.

But the real paradox is that, at the moment when the euro is at risk of failure, it should be the Danish presidency that saves it, a country, Denmark, outside the eurozone, because Denmark, evidently rightly, has never trusted the euro.
Mr. President, Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the increase in violations of intellectual property rights is recorded in the last years.
The years at risk of compromising the strategy on intellectual property rights in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.
In order to counter such phenomena and safeguard the success of the policy of protection of intellectual property, it has been proposed to entrust the sole
The tasks relating to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, established in 2009, are assigned to the Office for the Harmonization in the Internal Market.

This is in order to provide the Observatory itself with human and financial resources, to undertake actions to combat violations of intellectual property and awareness campaigns aimed at increasing consumer awareness of the risks associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.

The favourable vote expressed in the report thus represents a moment of great importance in the fight against the trade of counterfeit goods and in defence of innovation, growth and the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as employment and the safety of European citizens.
Thank you, President. Intellectual property may seem contradictory in itself as a definition, but it has great moments of coherence.

I voted in favor of this proposal because its purpose, which is to entrust the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market with some tasks related to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, is necessary and essential in order to fight against violations of intellectual property rights.

The main objectives are to increase awareness in the public and private sectors about the impact of counterfeiting in the footwear industry and to inform consumers about the dangers associated with the purchase of counterfeit products.
On the basis of the 33 compromise amendments, an agreement was reached in first reading on 19 December last.
The amendments provide that the title of the regulation and the name of the office are not changed in the sense of the European Observatory.
Moreover, the important and fundamental thing is the participation in the meetings by civil society.
All this will make a moment of synthesis, such as the one we are about to celebrate with today’s vote, even more democratic and participatory.
Thank you, Mr. President. The report by Eleonora Ecker inserts itself into that framework of actions aimed at improving services for citizens and businesses within the European Union.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is in fact an excellent tool to make communications and the retrieval of information by citizens and businesses more accessible and, above all, faster.
Therefore, Mr. President, I have cast my vote in favor.
Thank you, President. Every time the situation seems to be improving, new downgrades by rating agencies shake up the international markets.
Many European companies are in crisis and, in terms of employment, the number of people, especially young people, who are chronically looking for a job is increasing.
If austerity plans and the defense of the euro are necessary measures, then even more so are the deep revisions of the labor market at the national level, in order to relaunch the European economy.
Only by relaunching competitiveness will we give new confidence to investors and promote growth and new jobs.
Thank you, Honourable Bizzotto. I do not deny that the rights of homosexuals need to be protected. What I deny is that, in Italy, there are no families.

Homosexuals will never exist, simply because the family must be protected, the one that even the European Parliament should protect, the traditional family, the one formed by a woman, a man and their children.
All this seems to me to be a rather elementary thing.
This is the reality in Italy and in the other 22 countries.
Thank you, President. First of all, I join the affectionate greeting of colleague Lechner and also the evaluation of his work, which has proceeded with competence, tenacity and determination.

A meticulous job, every now and then this regulation proposal would get stuck and he would pull it out, he would start dealing with the Council, with the Commission, with the Legal Commission, I believe that he can be proud of this.
I see that the consensus is unanimous in your favor.

Coming to our regulation, I am also convinced that it is an important matter. Perhaps it does not make the news in the newspapers, perhaps it is not considered high politics, but the construction of the European Union also passes through
through a work of satisfaction of the interests of the citizens in their daily life and especially of these millions and millions who, living across different states,
They find themselves faced with difficult practices to untangle, boring, and sometimes they touch on sensitivities in the heart of a family that politics generally has difficulty seeing.
The European Union must be proud to base itself on such attention.
The solutions that have been proposed are smart and new. For example, the option has been given to those who have to make a will to choose between their usual residence or their country of origin.

This makes the decision more flexible, given that there are such deep differences, truly very deep differences, between one State and another, which could constantly put the issue of succession in difficulty.
However, legal certainty was also provided, because once the legal solution was chosen, whether habitual residence or country of origin,

It determines a limitation of the judges' discretion and also a limitation of the conflicts that can arise and therefore a more peaceful way of proceeding in this field and therefore there is more freedom and more certainty.

And then the certificate of succession. We believe that certificates are of little importance. This creates the conditions whereby the heir has a condition of greater flexibility and certainty in the face of all the possible difficulties that could arise.
It is a fact that positively characterizes this law.
It is true, this rule is not perfect, there are problems concerning the executor or not, the feasibility of direct inheritance and so on, but I just want to say one more word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council will approve this text. We hope that it will become a regulation. But we must not put a tombstone on this text, because we cannot even stay with the...
England in a different situation from Great Britain, because Europe cannot do without Great Britain, and so we will have to proceed to overcome these difficulties one by one.
Thank you, sir.
Mr. President, the European Union has produced an enormous quantity of laws, rules to build European law and has created the European area, called the Stockholm plan.
There is a mismatch between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use that citizens make of it, which is numerically and percentage-wise very low.
On the other hand, national judges and lawyers of individual states have grown up within the law of their own country and have a predominant training in this field.
We believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mentality and is imbued with the knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before talking about training, we must talk about a great communication to the citizens and to the operators of the law so that they become the carriers of this great novelty and increase the capacity to want to use the advantages of this right.

But above all, it is a movement from the bottom that must be created in the training in service. You cannot give a lecture as if to schoolchildren in the judicial training of adults and professionally very high.

It is necessary to stimulate curiosity in dealing with one's own cases, to connect with other colleagues and to find solutions, since today common law and civil law converge, they are no longer as distant as they once were within legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am happy that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects, in our convention we ask for a reversal of trend, bottom-up, more legal studies than judicial training.
There is an example in Holland called Eurinfra, which is very interesting. It is a network of people in charge in every court who spread this knowledge and encourage judges to do so.
Here is the substance of our project, we hope it can have support all the way to the end of the Commission.

Mr. President, I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the work done by colleague Giegel with this initiative report. I also recall that with him and with others we share an active presence in the intergroup social economy of this Parliament.

As you know, my political group believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, so not just one of many policies, but a policy that characterizes our project.

And in these times, with the attacks also linked to the need to cut public spending, etc., we still defend this priority, we know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it must be maintained, defended and reaffirmed as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that in this same vision we must also value economic entities that do business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and that have a very special role in the so-called European social economy. They are companies that...

They reiterate that it is possible to produce, to do good things, to be efficient, even if profit is not the goal, but rather employment, welfare, the valorization of work and the contribution to the life of the local community.

This is why it is important, and I conclude, Mr. President, that Europe makes available the useful tools for an active policy and a good statute, not the one we have now, which is unworkable, but a good statute for cooperatives can be a way to help this very important sector.
Thank you, Mr. President. The role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fair economic dimension.

At this moment, when we are going through one of the most serious economic and social crises since the end of the war, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial. It is indeed evident that wherever there is...

There has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, and consequently there has been an increase in employment, more qualified work, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary for there to be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation and this must come about by helping and not by creating bureaucratic obstacles.
For this reason I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to solve the problems mentioned.

The survival of millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the meager assistance offered by the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The data collected shows that most of the fund's beneficiaries are unable to find new employment, while the luckier ones are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, even for only six months.
In many cases, the unemployed are reluctant to apply for this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The FEG is not a solution and does not plug the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and with too much lightness by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of structural unemployment, Europe must put a stop to its excessive openness towards the markets of developing countries, whose real competition is the main cause of the failure of our companies.
As long as Europe does not stop promoting economic self-harm by defending a myopic position in relation to global trade flows, our companies will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is through training courses that our unemployed will find peace and security.
Yes, very briefly. I believe that today is a great result for the European Parliament, because when I wrote on July 15th...
President Buzek said that we must set up an anti-mafia commission, I remember that there were many colleagues from different countries who said that the mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy.

Today, having the colleagues from the North, from all over Europe, recognize that there is a problem of organized crime in Europe and having the will to fight together, I believe this is a very important fact and I want to say thank you, President, and thank you to the whole Parliament.
Two minutes. Yes, thank you Mr. President, thank you Mr. Sondal for the complete presentation.

I would also like to reiterate, first of all, our solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place on December 16 in Zanfara, as well as our concern for the subsequent developments of the events.

What was originally essentially a trade union warning degenerated into very serious incidents in which 17 people lost their lives and in the days following the incidents in the arrests of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in everyone's interest, and as the Kazakhstani has also shown in person, to shed full light on the events and I hope that today's meeting will be a positive opportunity for our Parliament to delve into what has happened so far.

and reiterate our appeal for an investigation that will ensure the international community that the responsibilities for the events in Sannoz will be clarified and the guilty parties pursued to the fullest extent of the law, with the utmost respect for the principles of legality and the protection of human rights.

The delegation that I have the honour of presiding over had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to listen to the explanations provided by the Kazakh authorities and also by some NGOs that are very active in monitoring events in this country.
The willingness of the Kazakh authorities to provide explanations, as well as the promises of further clarifications, are certainly positive elements that must obviously be appreciated by all of us.

For this reason, I would like to emphasize the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance that I would have liked to see highlighted in the text of the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow, and which, in my opinion,

In my opinion, it would perhaps have been appropriate to wait for the conclusion of the official investigations, which would have been useful to support with an official mission of international organizations.

The undeniable need to shed further light on what happened and the need to appeal for ever greater efforts to be made by Kazakhstan to improve progress on the road to democracy must also be constantly accompanied by renewed commitment and open constructive dialogue with this country.

I voted in favor of the present proposal, since it is necessary to update the regulations of 2004 and 2009 in order to adapt the changes of the national registration of the Member States in the field of social security, to keep up with the changes of the social reality that affect the coordination of the social security systems themselves.

The present proposal also includes proposals from the Administrative Commission for the Coordination of Security Systems, whose purpose is to improve, modernize and acquire in accordance with all that is established in Article 72, letter f, of the previous regulation.

The amendments contained in the present proposal aim, in fact, to guarantee legal certainty for the interested parties and, moreover, to ensure appropriate coordination at the level of the European Union of the national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes made at the national level and it was necessary to approve it because it takes into account the recent developments in cross-border mobility that affect the coordination of social security systems.

Thank you, Mr. President. The credibility of the European Union at the international level and the effectiveness of its policies in the field of human rights certainly pass through the condemnation of violations and abuses.

committed outside the context of armed conflicts, the lack of respect for women, minors, in general the weakest, and persecutions based on religion or belief, but it is of absolute importance to also avoid the disparity

between the criteria of the European Union's human rights policy and its other external policies, thus promoting democratisation and supporting the fight against social inequalities, especially in times of economic crisis such as the present.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to thank colleagues Arsenis, Patraoneves and Romeva and their assistants for having contributed substantially to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common good, as it provides 15% of the proteins to over 3 billion people and the life of over 500 million people depends on fishing and aquaculture.
This makes it a true global public good.
The approval of this declaration indicates to the Commission a precise path on the need to spread responsible conduct, both among fishing communities and in consumer behavior.

The debate on the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy has, as of today, one more reason to support actions that will take European policy out of the narrow focus on the methods of resource extraction and on a policy of rules all directed inwards.

On the contrary, a strategy is suggested for the sea as a privileged place to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative modalities of fishing agreements with third countries.

Moreover, all this is not only about environmental protection and biodiversity maintenance, but also about responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, and the precise interest of fishermen and our economies.
Thank you, President. The third amendment to regulation 1000...
COM (2003) 2006, presented by the European Commission in a short time, contains provisions aimed at creating a European instrument for risk sharing.

The objective is in fact to face the difficulties encountered by some Member States in collecting the private funding necessary for the implementation of investment projects that can only be partially funded with the use of public funds.

Although the path to overcome the economic crisis is still long, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text fruitful, which has set a maximum for the funds intended for the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing instruments.
Please, I would like to speak. Thank you, President. The economic crisis, technological development and demographic changes have changed society and the labour market in Europe in recent years.
To meet future skill demands, many people will need to complete higher education. Many workers will need to continuously update their skills and knowledge while already employed.

For this reason, I have expressed my favorable vote for the text of colleague Tokes, which aims to modernize higher education systems to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and promote social, cultural and economic development within the Union.
Yes, thank you, President. I will not take too long because in the little time I have I would like to mention only a few things.

I believe that this seventh action program for the environment can certainly be a useful tool, but only if it is based on a vision of the future that takes into account the need to maintain a solid European industrial base, which is essential to maintain a dignified and acceptable level of employment.
There are some things that worry me.
I believe that an absolute priority is that this framework, that this program ensures the most effective implementation of the existing regulation before setting new ones.

further binding targets. And I am deeply convinced that, in order to face today's environmental challenges, we must base ourselves on future environmental policies that are based on solid evidence, on the most up-to-date scientific knowledge.

I am concerned about Article 24, which speaks of the ecological footprint as an absolute indicator. It represents an indicator, an empirical model of reality, not reality itself. We must keep this in mind.

This has many limits, it tells us how much we affect the environment, but it does not estimate the quality of the environment at all. So my concerns remain and I invite everyone to take them into account.
When we talk about good examples for citizens, when we talk about the internal market and the possibility of creating opportunities,
Real opportunities for concrete change in everyday life through the internal market. We can really use this example, and we will obviously need many others as a result of our work.
It is a good example because, as was said, it affects the concrete life of citizens, their daily life, it also helps companies to expand their market, not because costs are high and services are...
reduced, but because they can increase the supply of services and, in essence, also help the economy as a whole. So I believe it is certainly a positive example, a good example.

However, you will have understood, Mr. Commissioner, that there is a very widespread will in this Parliament, in particular I recall the interventions of two of my colleagues, Marturè and Goebbels, of my group, but also many others.
Others would like this good example to become excellent and for us to move towards, and this measure partly provides for this, a zero roaming result, because it is possible.
We are utopians.

No, because the European internal market provides for similar rates between domestic and non-domestic, there is no difference if we are talking about a single market, and above all because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when in 2007 we started talking about voice roaming, the first roaming of the third which we are.
There was a certain incredulity and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission, I must give credit to its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

Difficulties were widespread, coming from those who said that the position of a real market does not provide for tariff regulation, that these are political prices, that they belong to an old left-wing conception, etc. etc. Others said that it does not work, and so on, it slows down the market, but in the end we did it.
The interest of the citizens and the realization that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs led to the referendum.
So the world is traveling, things are becoming more and more possible, for this reason I think that an even more courageous result is possible.
Last observation, because there are no other possibilities. Today we had a delegation of Tunisian citizens, I don't know if they are still present.
Well, perhaps among the many benefits, this extra-UE expansion makes us understand that the possibility of using it without the scare of costs also helps democracy.
In Europe, there are more than 120 million broadband users, at least 70 million citizens who use their mobile device to connect to the Internet, work, study or simply to get informed.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favor of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone traffic, voice, data and SMS.
A positive decision because the price reduction program will lead to an average 35% drop in tariffs over the next three years.

However, this is not enough. In a difficult time like the current one, both from an economic and an employment point of view, communication, new technologies and innovation are a primary good that Europe must defend with more courage.
Every European citizen must be able to travel freely between Member States, using the telephone tariff set by their national operator.

Enough with frauds and exorbitant bills for those who travel within the EU. If we really want to give a concrete response to citizens, let's create a sort of Schengen for telecommunications, which no longer imposes different tariffs on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Thank you, President. Colleagues, I was part of that delegation of the European Parliament that went to Sicily last November.

Our head of delegation, Cecilia Wikström, wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the Minister of the Interior, and we received a response that gave us a fairly clear situation, that gave us fairly clear answers.

I would like to recall above all the fact that after that visit to Italy the government changed and the approach to the situation changed as well, but the situation itself in the countries from which the migratory flow mainly came changed as well.
However, this should not prevent us from the need for a careful analysis of what has happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that is still current today is the status of Lampedusa as an unsafe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center of Contrada Imbriacola following the fire of the
in September 2011, which damaged it, but only partially, that is, one dormitory destroyed, one damaged, out of seven buildings in the structure, and then the de facto suppression of the project.

Presidium. Now, apart from the consideration that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was that of Tripoli in the time of Gaddafi, and this analogy does not seem to me to be very appropriate, given that migratory flows, even if reduced in number, also for seasonal reasons,

They certainly have not stopped. It is important that a first aid and reception activity works and works in Lampedusa, which is the first stop for those arriving from the other side after journeys that are certainly not easy or risk-free, and the Somali shipwrecked people who arrived in

In April of this year, after seeing ten people die on the boat they were traveling on, or the twenty who were transferred to Linosa because there was no room in other reception centers, or the eighteen who still live in the stadium locker rooms in Linosa.

The tourist residence Calacreta, where they are currently hosted, is certainly not a CIE or a CARA, and above all, in the meantime, both the health system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the goodwill and the good heart of the Carabinieri, the citizens and the volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is that of the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.
Having allowed, against every legal and ethical norm, thousands and thousands of people to gather in a place that, due to its capacity and intended function, could only accommodate a few hundred,

The passage, having allowed a territory of a few square kilometres, already difficult due to its position and logistical difficulties, to be forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own inhabitants, must be reviewed.
reflecting on the responsibility for a situation of extreme tension that then exploded in violence.
in the fire itself. I believe
I believe that the excellent report by colleague Rinaldi was successful in the classroom.
I fully share the opinion of Mr. Losinghiero on the report.
However, I would like to raise a small issue. Our Europe, compared to this new world that is trying to find democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to pay, both in terms of environmental aspects and in terms of the economic transactions that take place in the Mediterranean.
The Mediterranean is a fishing area.
We are building a new fishing policy in Europe that will establish very strict rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules.
And so why not use fishing agreements, support for these countries so that these countries apply the same rules that are applied in Europe?

This would be a good thing for European fishing, for the sea, for environmental conservation, to make this fragmented area less fragmented and more of a homogeneous place on which to build the future of Europe and of this new world.

With the Lisbon Treaty in force, the European Parliament has become a full institutional player in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to actively and decisively participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the Union's security model.

The report by colleague Borsellino defines the five key sectors for which concrete actions have been proposed and hopes for greater judicial and police cooperation between member states to tackle organized crime and terrorism.

I believe it is of particular importance to take into strong consideration the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools to guarantee a space of freedom, security and European justice. Thank you.
With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law in Community law.

While the importance of mutual recognition, harmonization of protection rules, and the principle of presumption of innocence remains, it is good to emphasize how the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, so as to make it clear to everyone which actions constitute a crime.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal to national law.
Any lack of clarity could in fact lead to divergent interpretations of the law.
I therefore believe that only close cooperation between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can ensure a coherent and high-quality European strategy in criminal law.
Thank you, Mr. President. The European Union guarantees the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising, and abusive contractual clauses.
There is no doubt that those consumers who are more vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems, or simply due to a lack of appropriate information, must be protected more carefully.
I therefore expressed my vote in favor of the test of colleague Perez because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer rights
the so-called most vulnerable, contribute not only to their social inclusion, but also to ensuring a single market that is safer, fairer and more competitive.
Yes, Mr. President, the report by colleague Perez, which we have voted in favor of, focuses on the need to consider the drafting of a

The strategy is aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop for this purpose.
The conditions of consumer vulnerability stem from causes of various natures and potentially can affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside that of the general consumer and to arrange a targeted strategy that, taking into account the composite nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions is not able to consider all the facets of the issue and the various possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other hand, it prevents the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to reach a definition of specific and targeted protection measures.

Thank you, thank you President. The management of the red tuna fishing has a long and rather complex history since the 1990s and is probably the one most strictly regulated by the European Union to date.
Despite the large investments in control matters having led to greater compliance with the rules, there are still concerns about the problem of overfishing.
I have therefore expressed my support for the Romeva-Irueda report, which proposes a reduction in the allowable catch rate, greater control and strengthening of measures to reduce capacity.
Thank you, President. The relations between the European Union and China clearly show situations of commercial imbalance.
It is therefore the duty of European institutions to make an effort to help European companies to get out of the crisis and to make access to international markets more equal.
I have therefore expressed my support for this report, sharing in particular, among the issues raised by the rapporteur, the application of the principle of reciprocity to the
Relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition on international markets and the request for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Thank you, President. The road is still long, but today's step can be an important one towards the introduction and application of a tax on financial transactions.
I understand the caution, the prudence, the need for gradualness expressed by Commissioner Scemetta and the technical problems mentioned by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to give stimulus and impetus to the necessary initiatives to address the problems that remain open, especially at the Council level.
We all want to carefully evaluate the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic of the proposal of exemptions.
If you are careful to reduce the impact of the tax, then it is important to have the broadest possible tax base with a low rate and not try to extend exemptions in an unlimited way.

To those who are concerned about the impact on small investors, I would like to remind you of the progressive nature of the tax, which means that those who make more transactions and more transactions are more affected.
transactions, and it is clear that the competent authorities will in any case have to monitor that there is no attempt to pass on any costs to clients and end users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote in favor of this tax by a large majority.

Thank you, President. Since 1990, through the instrument of macro-financial assistance, the European Union grants economic aid in the form of grants, loans or a combination of both to countries in difficulty with the balance of payments in the short term.
The rather long timeframes, added to the difficulties highlighted by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some changes to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make the evaluation criteria faster and more effective and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the disbursement of macro-financial assistance.
Thank you, President. There are around 100 million European citizens working in various voluntary activities.

From major sporting events to cultural events, the role of volunteers is crucial, and the work of those who rush to provide help and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters should not be overlooked.
Volunteering is one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I hope for the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the elimination of the current obstacles.
Thank you, President. From the communications sector to finance, transport, energy, from culture to health, the role played by technology is increasingly relevant.
The increasingly frequent use of the Internet and digital media makes the problem of cybersecurity one of the priorities of the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can in fact promote economic and social development only if the current regulations guarantee the security of users in terms of data confidentiality and intellectual property rights.

For this reason, only full international cooperation involving member states, institutions and industries in the sector can give rise to a solid system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cyber security.
Thank you, Madam President, and thank you to the Commissioner, who said important things, which are very shareable.
I find it truly, as he said, shocking that we have all experienced this in our own countries, with the numbers and figures we heard earlier from colleague O'Connor.
But it is equally clear that this scandal has really highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the gaps we have discussed so far in the House, which the Commissioner has so well represented, so I would not like to dwell on this aspect in the short time I have available.
I believe it is good to put in place everything necessary so that we can offer the best to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so many things, could also be a starting point to take another step forward. I refer to what the colleague said before.

The communication that is made to patients is really poor. Only the positive aspect is always emphasized. It is said that there is a sort of eternal youth, a promised beauty. There are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when talking about pure cosmetic surgery, should really be communicated to people, to girls, because we know that there are very young people who approach this type of intervention.
So, I see that you are absent with conviction, so I urge you, let's work, the times are tight, we should have done it yesterday.
Thank you, President. The Council Regulation on the multi-annual plan for the herring stock was adopted before the entry into force of the Treaty and therefore an alignment was necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fishing sector to be aligned with the Treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, since the solution adopted in this case could affect the decision-making procedure applicable to other multi-annual plans.
For this reason, I express my vote in favor. Thank you, President.
Thank you, President. From Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there have been numerous environmental disasters in recent years that have affected Europe and put the health of European citizens at risk.

The text of colleague Ader concerns the revision of the Seveso II Directive, which aims to contain the effects of those incidents connected with significant quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances dispersed in the environment.

The revised standards, which will come into force from June 2015, are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, limiting tragic consequences for the health of citizens. I therefore cast my vote in favour.
Thank you, President. I also thank Stevenson for the excellent work and the approach he has given to this report, which substantially addresses the two main issues.

This is not just a simple management plan for herring, it is essentially about guaranteeing the future of fishermen in some ways and planning at sea to ensure that this, in a multi-year manner, has its safeguards.
However, the key point of this report is and remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council should accept the approach given by the Treaty of Lisbon and I also think that it is time for the Parliament, in some way, with a voice perhaps more authoritative than that of the
a debate within the Fisheries Committee or a debate on a report concerning herring, have the courage to take a very clear and strong position with regard to the issue of delegated acts.
We claim the right that on these matters there is really the ordinary procedure.

I am perfectly aware that the issue also involves, besides many other fishing sectors, which will be aggravated with respect to the reform that is underway, but it concerns issues that regard agriculture and other topics.
The essential passage is respect for the will of Parliament.
In drafting this report, the directly interested parties, the road transport companies, were not taken into account at all.
In Italy, 91% of goods transport is by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this agreement is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden that weighs on our companies, but relations like these undermine
all our efforts, because they will stifle the companies themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with ruinous economic losses and with new forms of unfair competition.
It would have taken little to obtain a balanced report that did not forget the survival issue of our companies in a very difficult economic period. But a dialogue of this type was not possible.

On the contrary, the report has deliberately ignored even the previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 directive on working time. It has even ignored the documents of the European Commission, with which the dangerousness of practices such as retrofitting was recognized, which is instead proposed again in this report.

The document that we will vote on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements that have been made in recent years and to pay the costs will once again be the European companies.

Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a very serious political mistake. Let's leave aside the legal aspect. It has caused a reaction in the world of immense proportions and this alone is enough to say that it was a political mistake.
And why the Benci?
Because it created the suspicion that access to the web, which is a great modern revolution, would be closed.
And why is this?
Because he made the mistake of putting together counterfeiting and piracy, which are two clearly distinct phenomena.
The way to fight counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.

And then another mistake, which has cut out Parliament from an important activity that it has been carrying out for some time, which is that of creating a new copyright, a new author's right. Now, this, while some would like to preserve the

The old copyright that existed before the web. So the point is that we have to work on copyright and put ACTA aside, which is an obstacle, and reject it and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, the Commission, after months and years of hesitation, has brought two important measures, the orphan works and the next one, the one on copyright management societies, to the attention of Parliament.
This is the advantage. So, we work on this by thinking with our mind and not only with our emotions, but without having a stake in the game.
Thank you, President. Simply to add my voice to the applause that this report has received in the Chamber, in relation to the need to strengthen the capacity of the European Union
of being a place where it is possible to invest, produce and produce with the aim of our conception of a socially inclusive economy and environmentally sustainable.

So I believe that some indications here are very useful in this measure, others can be added and I believe it is important to take this indication, to work more and more because the attractiveness is the
As a result of territorial policies, territorial marketing, opening up, which are on the part of the territory the proposal of a productive, industrial vocation.

A manufacturer of services that, born from the territory, is respectful of all environmental compatibilities. And together European policies that go in this direction. From the territory and from Europe, a voice that is attractive for investments and for growth.

Thank you, President. When we talk about delicate issues such as the authorization of products and substances for use in organic farming, we are talking about the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is important, in fact, to meet the expectations of consumers regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets and it is also important to ensure adequate application of Community legislation by the authorities, bodies and operators concerned.
For this reason, I have expressed my favorable vote for the colleague’s text.
The first comments on the Council have begun the phase of reductive reading and this is wrong because important steps forward have been made.
For example, think of the breakup of the destructive ties between banks and public debt, and the weak level of employment.

It seems that the spirit of recovery and of a renewed path of political unity is returning to European institutions, after so much slowness and so much lethargy, and a will for real progress towards greater integration.
And today we have recorded a strong unity between Parliament and Commission on this.

I am not talking about winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis of the community spirit.
There was an initiative and activism by several countries, not to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common consensus respectful of all member states.
This is the path of the political objective of unity, without which any banking, fiscal and monetary union will be totally insufficient.

With the decision of the Council to give Member States the possibility of reintroducing border controls, a new Europe was born in June, a Europe that is courageous in fulfilling the desire of its citizens.
It is inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, which is redirected towards the defense of the rights of its peoples, above all.

To President Schulz, even if he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an inter-institutional incident, but rather a respect for the will of the citizens and not for that Euro-bureaucracy that for years has pretended not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary flow of illegal immigrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants measured by Frontex of 35% in 2011.

I am only sorry that the scenes of political showmanship consumed in this last plenary session have taken time away from a more useful and constructive activity, to question ourselves on why it was not us but the Member States who defended the interests of our citizens.

If Parliament does not find its soul and the courage to go against the goodism and the sterile obviousness on which it has been stuck for too long, it will continue to be a follower and not a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr. President, I would like to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday a
It has been officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
The particle that gives mass to all the others and their existence, and this has happened in European soil.
Science gives life to our land, civilization and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to become a world capital of science again.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it. And it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of man that today a person...
A blind person who has no eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears. And a young South African man who has no legs can run in the Olympics in a sprint race.
Well, Europe must be the homeland of science. This great event, which will open new frontiers to knowledge, must be fully supported by Europe.
Thank you, President. Too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not file a complaint due to fear or lack of trust in the institutions.
The text voted on today tends to strengthen the rights of crime victims and to guarantee them the same level of protection, assistance and access to justice throughout
in all the countries of the Union, paying particular attention to those victims who are at high risk of suffering further harm or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

It is therefore of particular importance to recognize the status of victim not only for people who have suffered damage as a result of a crime, but also for the family members of the person who died as a result of the crime.
On September 11, the Catalan people peacefully demonstrated in Barcelona.
A million people have asked for the independence of Catalonia from Spain.
On 15 October last year, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum on Scottish independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in the last few weeks thousands of people have signed a petition to hold a referendum for the independence of Veneto from Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, in Lombardy, in all the regions of the North, hundreds of thousands of people signed to have more autonomy from Rome.
But also in the Basque Country, the citizens are loudly demanding autonomy and independence from the national states.
And what does President Schulz say?
It requires a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy, Vidal-Quadras, even went so far as to invoke the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are a very serious act, contrary to the principles of that democracy that we preach here and that we must defend.
I tell them that it will be the people who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats of Brussels.
The road is already laid out.
The policy of austerity adopted to get out of the economic crisis has not produced the expected results.
As highlighted by the report of colleague Lavia, only by investing in a more selective way and supporting the ideal of a European budget that is more focused on
By supporting growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economy of the Member States, improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I have therefore expressed my favorable vote.
Thank you, President. The social and economic context in which the multi-annual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With Member States committed to making fiscal adjustments to their respective national budgets to balance public finances, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, to truly get out of the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the programmatic card of an institution. From the budget you understand what it is, what it does and above all what it wants to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a budget of survival, of dragging along, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments for employment, for innovation, for young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as stated by, among others, colleague Calfin, Europe can do today what the States can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is affirmed or destroyed, the life of the citizens we have talked about.
Today, major European choices risk being stifled by the budgetary disputes within the Council, but not only, between beneficiary countries, paying countries and paying countries.

We say that it is a false problem because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, from what has happened in the past, that contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working on putting figures next to the various headings.

The war of positions has begun, with statements and positions taken by some states that consider the budget to be subject to any expenditure item that can be cut without remorse, indeed perhaps useful to bolster an anti-European sentiment that is easy to solicit in times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position that does not help the integration we are trying to achieve in other fields.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as many of us have said.
We have adopted a stability pact that was also supposed to be a development pact, but we have become so stable that we are in recession.
Let's take this opportunity, at least, of this budget, of this multi-year plan, to make choices in the right direction.
Thank you, President. The lack of information and awareness of one's own rights, to which are added the obstacles
Linguistic barriers and the lack of recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems that EU citizens face when they live, study or work in another EU country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility of the notion of Union citizenship and its concrete advantages.
For this reason, I have expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to strengthen the awareness of the rights connected to the citizenship of the Union, to help citizens fully exercise their right to circulate and to stay freely in the territories of the Member States.
Mr President, the multiplication of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance and control of their effectiveness.
It is necessary to find a proper balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of action.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is, however, of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investments in the economy.

in a manner consistent with its own objectives, in a context in which the continuous decrease in the responses destined for the community budget is contrasted with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
Thank you very much. The Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts
the legislation of the Union, in that it has outlined the basis of a European judicial area, promoting legal certainty among European citizens.
The revision of this regulation touches on fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on...
On the competence of disputes with possible domiciled in third countries and the agreements on the choice of the competent forum.

I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can guarantee stronger protection for consumers and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I have expressed my favourable vote.

Mr. Commissioner, today Europe is asking for a new task of coordination of industrial policies and even the most severe supporters of the autonomy of private initiative are asking for the exercise of this role.
Without a greater Europeanization of national strategies, even in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The crisis in the car industry is not just about overcapacity, it is also about the dramatic loss of jobs.
But the crisis now seems to be structural and concerns the very destiny of the car, of the product as it is today.
We want to keep the car industry in Europe and we do not want to lose the existing skills, the know-how, the professional skills.
We therefore ask that a major restructuring and relaunch project be started, and that it be done in a short time, as costs are proportional to time.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or of individual companies.
We must at least try to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, putting the interested parties around the table with social dialogue.
producers, trade unions and the governments of individual countries, by supporting research, innovation, the formation of human capital, requalification, the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective community impulse and guidance to face together the increasingly aggressive global market.

Thank you. The energy crisis is making and has made a very high price to be paid by all employment, thousands of precarious workers, but also stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly turning towards the Far East or the American continent, and this raises a major question about the direction of our development model.
I think that Europe must recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic productions capable of supplying the internal European market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, we will support you, Mr. Commissioner, if we want to stop the industrial decline.

I believe that we must step out of a dualism, which tonight is not present, but which is often felt in discussions on this sector, a dualism between supporters of the environment and that of workers, which is wrong because it does not allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that sees steelmaking as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard the different interests and needs.

Therefore, strong planning is needed, even at the European level, aimed at sustainability, which we must not go back on, in my opinion, as a key added value with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments as has been said.

As stated by many, new technologies, new processes, the requalification of plants for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, also energy resources, indeed starting from energy resources and also on the research of new and different materials.

Yes, thank you President. As we have recalled in this room, next December the United Nations agency dedicated to communication and information technology will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The object is the renegotiation of international regulations on telecommunications.

We cannot forget, and I am happy with the words of Commissioner Tajani, the work that has been done so far, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure such as the UN, of which we know that hundreds of states from all over the world are part, many of which are known for problems related to democracy, transparency and freedom of expression.
Therefore, it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the Internet, namely freedom, participation, openness and innovation, are in danger.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet, and the role that the Internet can have in relaunching economic growth, but not only that, also to guarantee opportunities for all.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards the goal of a united Europe at Dubai that speaks with one voice.

There are many controversial proposals presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications. In particular, those that envisage changes to the governance of the Internet, which call into question the neutrality of the network, with negative repercussions on consumers.
The freedom of the Internet is therefore in danger, or more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would in fact allow a government to snoop not only on the communications of its own citizens, but even on the data that travels on its own networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely brief and therefore I believe it is in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Thank you, President. I have expressed my support for the colleague's text. In particular, I agree with the rapporteur in underlining the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the efforts of the European Union aimed at improving and coordinating training in the field of jurisdiction for legal authorities, judicial and administrative, for legal professionals.
All initiatives in the sector should be intensified to fully achieve the concept of a Union based on the rule of law.

In order to face such situations and be less dependent on the import of hydrocarbons, Europe will therefore have to rely on its own possible reserves of gas and shale.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized the search for shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase, should the discovery allow it.
In a context of this kind, it is necessary to monitor the regulations relating to shale gas extraction within the borders of the Union, so that the effects of its
Undoubtedly valid from an economic point of view, these extractions do not create environmental problems due to the possible release of harmful substances into the aquifers and the atmosphere.
Thank you, Mr. President. I believe that today should be the occasion to talk objectively about Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country in terms of stability and the strategic future of Central Asia and is undoubtedly an important economic and commercial part of the European Union.
It is a country that has already started a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but it still has to work hard to fully implement these processes.

It is, however, a country that, with this objective, persists in demonstrating that it is also ready for new and more solid reforms and I believe that this is the task of the European Union to accompany it.

This is why I am certain that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow us to move forward, because its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and will ensure constant support from the European Union.

I am also convinced, and I believe this should have been even more evident in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress on the road to democracy and human rights should be accompanied by renewed and reciprocal open and constructive commitment.

Our goal should not be to put ourselves in a negative position with these and other countries in front of the immediate implementation of changes. Our goal should be to support the efforts of these countries to achieve the goal of respecting the principles of human rights.

Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteurs of the reports that we will vote on tomorrow. Just a brief comment on the spin-off, and I associate myself with what I heard tonight as a unanimous voice from all colleagues.
But I wanted to focus on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera relationship, which I greet and congratulate.
I wanted to say one thing: with the past common fisheries policy, only the gap between the institutions that regulate fishing and its stakeholders, i.e. the fishermen, has been increased.

Unfortunately, up to now, in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has penalized those who have always considered fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas and their cuisine.

This is how the conviction grew that the line followed by the European Commission was to standardize all fishing in Europe under the large industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the reasons of thousands of fishermen who for a couple of years

For decades, they have been operating according to rules that are related to the conservation of the ecosystem, which I can only agree with, but which have never preserved the work activities of the micro-economy of artisanal fishing.
This initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission and can be translated into practical actions to the benefit of the small-scale fishing economy.
The report, in fact, highlights a series of advantages, the allocation of a minimum sum to small-scale fishing from the European Fund,

It will be necessary to encourage projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole and, moreover, it will be essential, Commissioner, to encourage young people's access to

We have talked about this sector several times in the Commission, because if not, not only will fishing probably die out due to the lack of seas and fish, but it will probably die out because young people are no longer approaching this sector.
This relationship is the opportunity to include there moments of training and incentive towards young people who want to approach the sector.

Thank you, thank you President. Finning is an unacceptable practice from an environmental point of view, as it threatens the sustainability of some shark species.
social and economic, since it implies the waste of a food product with commercial value, as well as from an ethical point of view, since it shows a total lack of respect for animal life.

Although such practice has been banned since 2003 in the waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating also the derogation to the ban on the export of shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.
